LONDON,Printed by Iohn Legatt. 1641.

list.item: AN admonition to the Reader of the order of the booke, and authors from whence it was gathered.
A preface wherein the judgement by urine is preferred before that by the pule. Alo the generation of urine in mans body.

Cap. 1. Generall coniderations in judgement of urines, how many things hinder judgement in repect of the urinall, phyitian, and urine it elf to the 5. page, and how many things alter the urine in repect of age, exe, complexion, time of the yeare, kinde of life, &c. to the 10. page.

4. Of 21. colours of urine, pag. 25. where the reader mut adde after pale, ubpicous, ubpallidus, thee words. If you eethe a piece of the rinde of pomegranate, and then put to it thrice as much clean water, it will make a pale colour. Alo at flaxen, piceus, adde thee words. But if you put thereto a little or none of cleane water, it will be flaxen colour.

Drops of fat, 90.

div.head: An admonition to the READER.
div.p:
THis Treatie following I firt digeted into tables for mine own privat ue, which afterwards was by my friend converted into this forme to fit the pree. And therefore the tudious reader mut till remember how one part followeth another in order: and that which is poken generally before a diviion, to be undertood of all the members following under that head according to the law of method. A word is enough to him that is acquainted with tables. The Treatie it elfe is an abridgement wholly gathered out of other mens writings, I challenge nothing to my elfe but the collection and dipoition hereof. Wherein for better atisfaction of the Reader, I have many times cited the Author, whoe tetimony I
ue, and now and then I have quoted the page of uch books as I then followed, and whereof I et downe the catalogue, where, when, and in what forme they were printed.

div.head: The Preface.
div.p:
AMongt all ignes of icknes or health wherby the skilfull Phyitian is led into the knowledge of the tate of the body, two are of mot general and certain ignification which are taken from the pule and urine, without which all the knowledge of phyicke beides, is obcure, doubtfull, and uncertain. Whereof the firt heweth the etate of the heart and arteries, the econd of the liver and veins. Both of uch peciall ue in ignification of dieaes incident to mans body; that joyned together, they certainly intruct the Phyitian whether the dieae tendeth to health or death, but whether of thee two everally conidered doth give more certain ignification, I had rather leave it to be determined of others who can better doe it then my elfe: yet under their correction me thinke that the urine giveth the mot manifet certaine and generall ignification of
all dieaes; becaue with the blood it is conveyed into all parts of the body, and from thence returneth backe againe in the veines to the liver and veels of urine, bringing with it ome note of the tate and dipoition of all thoe parts from whence it commeth. Neither is there any other excrement that hath o many differences as the urine, neither from which o many ignificatio¯s may be taken as from it, in the ubtance, colour, quantity, contents, mell, manner of piing, &c. in which the Phyitian may with more profit exercie himelfe then in the ix differences of pules, the art whereof Hippocrates either never knew, or neglected. And Galon confeeth of himelfe, that he pent 20. yeares in tudy that way, before he could attaine the knowledge of the (ytole) or contraction of the pule in the arteries, which being unknowne, the pule alo mut remain unknowne; and yet it is uncertaine whether Galen indeed ever did attain therto. From Galens time for 1200. yeares after, this knowledge lay buried in the black dungeon of ignorance, untill Ioephus Struthius brought it to ome light: and no marvel; for the continuall mutability and alteration of the pule cannot be comprehended by art.
For as the affections of mans minde, anger, feare, joy, orrow, love, hatred, pringing from the heart doe vary; o the pule differeth in every moment. So we read that Eraitratus the Phyitian perceived by the pule of Antiochus on to the King of Syria and Peria, that he was in love with Stratonica his tep-mother. And Galen aith that hee perceived by the often change of the pule of a woman, that he was in love with Pylades. Beides that, the tunicles of the arteries, the skin and fleh in the wret of the hand where the pule is felt, and the skin and fleh of the Phyitians hand feeling the pule, are in ome harder and in ome ofter. Againe, the patients hand differing in heate or cold, or manner of poition, higher, lower, or on the one ide, and the Phyitians hand touching the arteries oftly, or preing them, and infinit other circumtances which make uch udden and momentary alteration of the pule that as in ancient time, o at this preent amongt us there be very few skilfull in this part of judgement. But on the contrary ide in urine there is no uch labour or caue of doubt, for we may ee it, and conider well of it, for many houres together, and find no alteration therein. And of this
Hippocrates, Galen, Aegideus, Actuarius, Avicen, and infinite others in all ages have delivered precepts, and gathered judgements, and therefore as a part of phyicke better knowne, and of more certainty then the pule, I have in this hort Treatie handled, divided into his differences, and to every difference I have added his judgment together with a reaon thereof. And in many places I have more epecially ditinguihed it, not onely by other differences of the urine, but alo by other accidents of the dieae it elfe. As for example, pag. 47. one ignification of much urine is a conumption of the whole body, whereto I have added other ignes by the urine, as that it is omewhat fatty, in colour palew, reddih, high coloured, and without other igns of concoction. And hereof I preently annexe this caue; for o the profitable fat, moiture, humors, and ubtantiall parts of the body are molten, diolved, and voided by urine. The ret I leave to the diligence of the tudious reader, who with mal conideration may eaily conceive the ame. And here I would make an end, but that I thinke it not amie in few words to hew the generation of urine in mans body, and the veels thereto belonging.

The meat and drinke received by the mouth, and decending downe into the tomacke, and there concocted together, incorporated and made one ubtance (chylus) and thence paing by an iue in the bottome of the tomacke (pylorus) to the firt gut (duodenum) and from thence to the hungry gut (ieiunum) from thence againe five of the eight mearaicall veines ucke o much as is profitable nourihment (the ret being unprofitable for nourihment is voided by toole) which againe is conveyed into vena porta, and at length after many purifications and concoctions in the parts before mentioned; to the liver, where it is converted into blood, and thence ent into the hollow veine, where it is againe more purified, the excrementitious parts being equetred, eparated, and ent to other places, as the choler to the gall, melancholy to the pleen and the watery or wheyih part to the emulgent or ucking veines, from whence againe it is drawne of the reines where it is altered perfectly into urine, which as unprofitable decendeth into the waterconduits (ureteres) and the¯ce into the bladder which at length at a mans pleaure by help of the mucle hutting the necke of
the bladder is voided out by the yard. Yet ome part of this thin wheyih humor is not after this ort conveyed from the liver to the bladder, but as I have hewed, cap. 12. is together with the blood in the veines derived into all parts of the body, and at length returning backe againe the ame way, is expelled by the yard. Seeing then urine paeth through o many veels, and receiveth o many concoctions and preparations before it can be expelled, it mut needs admit many alterations. And yet we ee by daily experience that great drinkers, thoe which drinke ome diuretike potion, and epecially thoe who are troubled with the piing evill, doe pie out preently after drinke not concoct, nor much altered from the drinke received. Hereof Galen 3. de facult. nat. cap. 15. yeeldeth thee reaons. The great deire of the tomack to receive drinke, the thin, piercing, and ubtle ubtance of the drinke peedily running into all parts: the widenee of the paages, and latly the trong attractive faculty of the reines, all which concurring together, doe caue the drinke received o quickly to pae through the parts of the body without any great alteration. Yet ome the better to atisfie thee doubts have devied,
and by arguments laboured to confirme a readier and horter coure for the drinke received to pae to the reins by the wind-pipe, great artery (aorta) emulgent veines, and bladder. But becaue this opinion is o contrary to the reputed and received truth of Hippocrates, Galen, and all Phyitians, as alo that it imagineth another free paage (beide the meat-pipe, through the wind-pipe and lungs: whereas we find by experience that a little dut in travelling, or a crum of bread in eating falling into the ame is ready to choke a man, as a kernell of a raion did Anacreon the Poet; and that therefore nature hath ordained a cover for the wind-pipe (epiglottis) let in eating or drinking omething hould pae that way. And the Phyitians doe forbid much talke or diputation at meat, let the cover being opened thereby hould let omthing pae that way. I ceae further to commend it.

div.head: CHAP. I.
Of generall coniderations in judgement of Vrines.
div.p:
IVdgements of an urine are conidered in repect of the urinall of the Phyitian, & of the urine it elf. 1. The urinalIn repect of the urinal, which ought not to bee of any colour, for o it would alter the apparent colour of the urine. Not trait or broad beneath, which alter the contents. Not open in the top, for o dut or other filth might fall in: aire, cold, or heat might oone alter it. Not topped with Woollen or Linnen, for o lint or Cotten might fall in. Not too neere, nor too far off, for the ubtance too neere might appeare thicker: and too farre off, thinner. Aegid. 10. Argent. 91. contrariwie
in Wine and Vineger. Capivac. 88. Not uncleane within.

The Vrinall therefore ought to be a cleare glae, or pure chrytall, without any colour at all or notable thicknee. Broad, round, and oblonge below, and traiter above, conically acending like to a mans bladder which it repreenteth; that a fit place may remaine for the fahion of the ediment: and topped at the top with leather, paper, &c. that nothing fall in, nor ayre eaily get in.

Phyitian.2. In repect of the Phyitian, who may not ee the urine in a place either too darke, or by candle-light, for o the colour will appeare altered. Or ele too light, as the Sunne-beames make the colour more remie.

Therefore put your hand or a blacke cloth betwixt the light and the Vrinall on the oppoite part of the Vrinall, that the colour and contents may bee the better dicerned, and your eyes be not dazaled with the light.

Vrine. 3. In repect of the urine it elfe: wherein are conidered,
1. Collection.
2. Things that hinder judgement.
3. Differences.

1. Collection.Collection. 1. When nourihment is
perfectly digeted, which is commonly that which is firt made in the morning after the nights leep. For that which is made lately after eating or drinking, or fit of an ague, hath neither colour, conitence, nor contents, being not concoct. Argent 91.
2. Take the whole urine and not the part, o much as is made at one time; but mingle not urines made at everall times, but keep them everall both for quantity, colour, and contents.
3. When the urine is new made and yet warme, it is bet to ee the colour, ubtance, and perpecuity; at what time you may ee alo the quantity and mell.
4. When it is etled in the Vrinall fully it is bet to ee the contents and bubbles. You may well alo then ee the ubtance. Actuar. Fernel. 452.
5. Let it not be kept pat ixe houres, for being longer kept it waxeth corrupt. Arg. 91. ex Avicenna.
6. Yet it is good to ee the urine lately made, and oftentimes after to oberve the pereverance or alteration of the ubtance, froth, and perpecuity, &c. Salvian. 222.

Things which hinder judgement. 1.
Much haking of it, or pouring it out of one veell into another.
Things which hinder judgement. 2. Cold or winde to congeale it and make it turne thicke as in Winter: but being chafed at the fire it returneth again, except it be too long kept. Cap. 2.
3. Winde to move or hake it.

4. Placed in the heate of the Sunne, or neere the fire, whereby that which is thin and ubtile is drawne out, and the ret remaineth thicke, dreggy: and o ometimes the urine that was made thicke and troubled, by great heate of the fire waxeth cleere, and the pume or bubble vaniheth away, which otherwie would continue. Salvian. 227.
5. Meats and drinks lately taken before alter the colour, quantity, ubtance, and mell ometimes.

6. Medicines taken, as Rheubarb, Saffron, Cinnamon, broth of Cherries, make the urine yellow; Casia, blackih; Oyle of Bay, Henbane, or Vnguentum Martiatum anointed, ena rubia maior, Cantharides applied to any part of the body, reddih.
7. Exercie, fating, watching, labour, anger, feare, vomiting, weating, purging, &c. alter the colour, ubtance, quantity, contents.
8. Reines or Bladder affected hinder the judgement of the inner parts. Fernel.
Differences are either principall in the urine, or lee principall.
Principall differences of the urin. Principall are, 1. Subtance. Cap. 2.
2. Quality, and that either firt as heate exceeding perceived by the patient in making it, as in inflammation of the liver, or by the Phyitian touching the urinall with his hand.
2 Heate moderate or temperate.
3 Deficient or under temperate.
Or econd quality perceived. 1. by ight, as perpicuity, light through, or darke and troubled. Cap. 3.
Colour. Cap. 4.
Tate, but that being too bae for the Phyitian, we leave to peake of it.
Smell. Cap. 9.
3 Subtance and colour joyntly, Cap. 5.
4 Quantity, Cap. 6.
5 Contents wanting three regions, ediment, wim, cloud: where we alo conider ubtance, colour, quantity. Cap. 7. 8.
Contents deformed.
Contents duely knit.

Lee principall differences. Lee principall, which though they doe not immediately helpe to judge of the urine, yet they declare the nature of
the urine and griefs of the body. Such arie from the caues; as choler, melancholy, leep, watching, dieaes.
From the effects, ignifying health, death, griefes of the tomacke, head, liver, breat, veines.
From the manner of piing. Cap 10.
From uppreion of urine. Cap. 11.

The bet urine imply. The bet urine imply in a perfect and abolute temperate whole man, which is the rule of all the ret, is that which is made without heate, as in burning agues. Capivac. 83. without cold, Capivac. 11. paine, or tinch. Of colour palew or light affron, perpicuous moderately, Capivac. 113. Of ubtance meane. Of quantity likewie meane, like to the former dayes urine, and proportionable to the drinke received yeterday and other daies before, and omewhat lee becaue ome is pent and wated in the body. Having contents white, mooth, equall, etling downe to the bottome of the urinall, not having bubbles, filaments, or any other evill contents. Having ediment likewie white, mooth, equall, pyramidally acending, nor tattered, ragged, or dipered, neither cleaving together, o but that they depart aunder, the urinall being haken,
and acend lightly without trouble of the urine. And all thee thus continuing long. Montan. 46. B.
The bet urine in repect of age The bet urine in repect of age, exe, time of the yeare, kinde of life, complexions, is as followeth.
1 Firt for children, urine is bet of ubtance thicke. For thin is lethall. Salvian. 33. 206.
2 Of quantity much.

3 Of colour white a little by continuall feeding on milke, Salv. 204. or becaue choller or bloud to colour the urine reteth or is drowned by too much moiture. Alo by debility, long leep, much ret, which becaue they cannot well move, increaeth moiture and decaieth heate.
2 The bet for pringalls, hath ediment heaped and increaed, ubtance thicke, but rather inclining to thinne. Colour yellow or light affron: blacke deadly Salvian. 93. contents moe then in men.
3 For men that which is et down firt for a perfect rule of the ret.
4 For old men with ubtance thin, colour white, ediment little.

Sexe. 5 For women whole. In ubtance rather thicke then thin, darke, troubled,
with many things wimming in it, not o cleere as in men.
In colour declining from light or palew towards white with ome darknee.
Quantity much.
Sediment impure, much thicker and whiter then in mens urine.
Ditinction between men and womens urine is eaily knowne by often comparing them together. Fernel.

Time of the yeare. 6 In repect of the time of the yeare, bet urine beginning in the pring, of colour white and pale, quantity greater, contents more thicker and more raw. In the pring proceeding, colour from pale and flaxen to palew and light; contents meane, ubtance equall. In ummer beginning, colour palew and light affron, ubtance thinner, ediment thinner, white, mooth, equall. In Summer proceeding, colour yellow affron, ubtance very thin, ediment little, thinne and declining to white.
In Autumne beginning, ediment little yet without fault. In Autumne proceeding all meane.

In Winter beginning, colour white, ubtance thicker. Fernel. Contents moe and rawer. In Winter proceeding, colour
white, quantity greater, contents moe and cruder.

K • nde of Life. 7 In repect of the kinde of life, as wherein there is much exercie, fating, anger maketh commotion of pirits and humours, watching, meats of hot operation, the urine is more coloured, and ediments fewer at the beginning as long as thoe paions doe inflame the heate of the body, and there is moiture which may be kindled; but that failing, and the heate languihing and decaying, the colour waxeth more and more remie again. Argent. 36. Salvian. 71. o in agues beginning, the urine is white, after that (heate increaing) yellow, and red; and in declination the heate decaying, more remie again. So urine voided after large drinking is firt white, after more coloured, and at length returneth to his former colour againe and conitence.
And where there is much idlenes, gluttony, urfeits, leep, drunkennee, ue of cold meates, the urine is white and thicke, ediment much and crude, naturall heate being oppreed and uffocated.

Complexion. 8 In repect of complexions, the flegmatike hath urine of colour white, ubtance thicke, quantity increaed, and the ediment
more raw.
The chollericke yellow as pure gold, much coloured, and of ubtance thin.

The melancholike white, with a certaine dimnee, becaue melancholy is in quality cold and dry. But if melancholy be voided, in ubtance the urine is blacke, as in criticall evacuations of melancholy. Aegid. 37.
The anguine reddih with a certaine darknee, ubtance indifferent thicke

div.head: CHAP. II
Of the ubtance of Vrine.
div.p:
THe ubtance of urine is either
thin,
thicke,
or meane.

Thin ubtance.Vrine thinne as water, uch as every urine is of it owne nature, neither can it waxe thicke by eething having little earthly ubtance: neither congeale through cold in our bodies, which be hot as long as we live, is not of o good ignification as thicke urine, becaue it ignifieth crudity and debility: whereas thicke urine ignifieth
ome eparation and beginning of concoction, as alo trength of the expulive faculty to expell groe matter, and mixt with urine: but thin urine doth ignifie either.

Obtruction. 1. Obtruction in the veines or liver with an ague, of the reines and veels of urine without an ague by tough and clammy humours, cloddes of bloud, tumors, tone, fleh growing, whereby the thicker part of the urine is taied, and the thinner in mall quantity, as it were through a colander or trainer is let pae, and may be knowne by the paine in the obtructed part. Salv. 11.

Crudity. 2. Or crudity and lacke of concoction and eparation, through cold and want of naturall heate, or abundance of unnaturall heate in an ague, and other ignes of heate, as in imple ditemperatures without mixture of humours, as is eene in cold, much drinking of wine, water and drinke.

Piing preently after drinking, and epecially which provoketh urine, and taying not in the body untill humours be concocted to ihue with it to give it ubtance and tincture: for the econd urine taying longer, is thicker and more coloured,
and o the third and the fourth, as ooner or later, more or lee thicke and coloured, as concoction and heate is more or lee trong. Capiv. 103. and at length returneth to his former ubtance.

In the beginning of dieaes when all humors are raw and unfit to bee concoct, the urine is white and thin, and after that heate increaing is yellow and red, and in declination the heate decreaing more remie againe, untill he returne unto his former tate of health.
In furfetting, drunkennee, gluttony, and epecially piing preently after.
When the tomach is cold, whereby meate and humors are raw, and o ent to the liver.
When the liver of it elfe is cold and weake, receiving them raw from the tomach, and endeth them o to the reines. For the errour of the firt concoction is not taken away in the econd.
When the reines and veels of urine through weaknes are not able to draw or expell any humour but thin. Capiv. 86.
Colour white in children ignifieth death. Salvian. 24.
Likewie in weake perons.
And in harp dieaes. Argent. 24.
Continuance of the dieae, in intermitting agues, or trong perons.
Recidivation or returning againe of the dieae, being made on the criticall day.

Concluion of the humor. 3. Or thin urine ignifieth converion of the humour another way with ignes of concoction, and more coloured urine precedent, as to the whole body with paine in the whole body, and thin water long continuing, the humour regurgitating into all places, as in the mall Pocks, Meails, Impotumes, Dropie, Botches, and Felons. Aegid. 230.
Into the tomach, and caueth upbraidings and vomitings.
To the braine in a frenzie with a burning ague, and is mortall.
Galen never knew any ecape, Mont.
To the Liver with paine in the right ide.
To the pores of the skin in weat.
To the hort ribbes, arme-holes, necke, privy parts, gathering to an head, making an impotume.
To the belly in dropies beginning. For after the matter increaing, the urine waxeth thicker.
To the reines in Nephritide.
To the eat in the Hemerodes.
To the joynts, as to the huckle-bone in ciatica, knees, feet, hands in the gout, drawing humors to them. Argent 24.
To the guts, as in dyenteries, flixes, laskes, looenee.
To the cods in Hydrocele.
To the mother, as immoderate flux of the termes. Record.
To other parts that are weake and grieved whither humors fall. Or being inflamed, draw humors to them much like cupping-glaes.

Thick ubtance. Vrine thicke as yrrup boiled to his height, or yellow choler in the gall. Aegid. 23. is alwaies made by mixture of other humors, as bloud, choler, fleume not naturall, abounding melancholy, rawe humors, purulent matter, eed, gravell, or filaments. The farther placed from you the thinner it appeareth, and hath alwaies moates tirring up and downe contrary in both to Wine or Vineger, beides the mell. Argent. 29. which either may be cleered externally, being chafed at the fire, returning againe, (except it hath tood too long, or tood too long by the fire or in Sunne, Arg. 47. or uch as waxe thicke, and are turned by tanding in the
cold extinguihing the heate and pirits of the urine:) or may be cleered of it elfe in the Vrinall, the thicker and groer part etling downe to the ediment: and this hath alwaies a good ignification that good concoction now beginneth in the liver, and that which is concoct hath now ome forme though unperfect: but while the heate is fervent in the veins, ome terretriall matter is mixed therewith, which is not yet perfectly eparated by the heate. Looke after in the declination of the dieae. Wecker.

Or this thicke urine may not be clee
• ed though chafed at the fire, which commeth either from the veels and paages of urine, as the reines, bladder, yard, be
• ng too open and large. Fernel. 449. or
• xulcerated and apotumated, whereby
• he urine is tronbled, and with purulent matter, raw humor, or eed is white, of
• loud red, and ometimes with gravell and
• laments. All to be knowne by mell and
• riefe in the part. Fern. 39. Arg. 22.

Or ele it commeth from ome upe
• our member, as liver, plene, veines, tomacke, where it is alwaies an argument
• f heate oppreed and crudity; not that
• aturall heate is ditempered, but uffocated
through abundance of humours. Fern. 449. and is to bee undertood either of one urine made at the ame time, or many, urines made on everall daies, and everall times of the ickenee. As in the beginning, where it heweth abundance of groe, raw, and flegmaticke humours: which caue head-aches in tertian and quotidian agues, and uch urine now made, when as nature hath made no concoction or eparation, it is through weaknee of nature, of unnaturall heat (ymptomaticall and ill) and other ill ignes joyned withall, as feeble pule, old age, Winter weaknes: it is mortall, except in dieaes of choler, and bloud, which are oon concocted. Arg. 29. but with good ignes, as youth, trength, good ediment, continuance of the dieae not deperate Weck. 13. Sal. 36. 138. Cap. 100.

State, a better igne, becaue now naturall heat beginning to prevaile, doth eparate and expell humors, which nourih the dieae in trength of the patient, and other good ignes; otherwie, that unnaturall heat putrefactive beginneth to move the humors, as chanceth often in petilentiall agues, Weck. 13.

Declining, if thinne water was made
before ome daies, and after it is made, it cleareth in the Vrinall. Sal. 201. when as naturall heate hath made ome concoction, and o expelleth the humor offending, epecially being made on the criticall day, it is a very good igne, for thus many dieaes are cured, as the ciatica, gout. Sal. 37. paine in the joynts.

And when the humour offending is expelled, and the patient recovered, the urine returneth to his colour and meane conitence againe. Arg. 25. But if it waxe thin and white too uddenly, or hatily, before the humor be expelled, and the patient recovered, it eemeth the humor is converted another way, where it makes an impotume drawing to a head, or to the braine as before in thin urine: looke immediately before in thicke humor which cleareth of it elfe.

Mean ubtance. Meane urine, neither o thin as water, neither o thicke as beats water, but as white Wine or cleere Ale: which waxeth thicke in the glae, through caue externall, as cold or longer tanding: for o in Winter urines turne ooner then in Summer: and being neere the fire or heate returne againe, except the naturall heate of the urine be totally extinct by too long,
tanding, or by being in too hote a place as the un, or too long by the fire, or in warme water, whereby the heate and pirit of the urine is diipated, rarified, and evaporated out of the urine, Argent. 47. Thee two returne not.

Or through caue internall, Videl. 1. want of naturall heate: as old mens urines and thoe that are in recovery of their health, doe eaily change and waxe thicke, and being chafed at the fire returne again, except they have tood long, &c. 2. Abundance of humors which nature can neither concoct nor detaine, but is almot uffocated therewith, as their urines which have crammed themelves with meat & drink are more eaily turned and waxe thicke. And both thee in whole men doe ignifie health impaired, becaue heate hath entred into ome raw matter in the veines, and cleareth it by rarifying the parts thereof, which heate and pirits being expelled by externall cold, the urine becommeth thick, Wecker.

In icke men in the beginning, ill, becaue the concoction is of unnaturall heate. After the beginning with other good ignes, concoction of naturall heate: but with ill ignes crudity of unnaturall heate.

But if the urine continue meane in the glae, and yet after it hath etled, the thicker part falleth to the ediment, it ignifieth good concoction in the tomacke, liver, veines, and lively naturall heate. Fernel. 449.

div.head: CHAP. III.
Of clearenee and darknee of Vrine.
div.p: Cleare urine. VRine is alo either perpicuous, light through or cleare, through which a man may dicerne his knockles. Record. and is not all one with thin urine: for white wine is thin, and yet often darke, and not light through. Ditilled wine is thin in ubtance, yet troubled and darke. This ignifieth in whole men (if it be moderately perpicuous) perfit digetion, good humors, abundance of naturall heat, which at length doth eparate and ditinguih the hypotais.

In icke men if it be too cleare and affron colour, ignifieth yellow choler, unnaturall heate, as in agues. Weck. More
remie, or darker, crude, and white, flegmatike, and watry matter, and ignifieth cold, crudity, and continuance of the dieae, and the more coloured the better. Cappivac. 113.

But in judgement of cleere and perpicuous urine in icke perons, we mut alwaies conider how their urine was in their health. For if it be the ame urine that was in their health, it ignifieth no ill: but if it change from lee cleare to more cleare, and in colour affron; then choler is augmented: in white colour flegme, and contrariwie.

Dark urine Or that is darke, troubled, not light through, through which one cannot ee his knockles, is not all one with thicke urine, as Galen thought. Salvian. For fih-glew, horne, white of an egge, oyle, and glae molten, and blackih wine are thick in ubtance, yet cleare perpicuous, or light through. Fern. 450.

1. Hereof are three kindes, whereof the firt is darke accidentally by outward cold after it is made, as by cold ayre, cold water, winter: and this of all other is mot thicke and darke, and doth taine the Vrinall, epecially in the crowne or top, with a certaine white clammy thin
humor, which being chated at the fire, or in warme water, returneth to it elfe againe as it was made (except it hath tood too long, Cappivac. 107.) whereby the inward heate of the urine is wholly extinguihed. But that ome urines more, ome lee, ome ooner, ome later, ome carcely at all waxe dreggy, thicke, troubled, and darke, is to be imputed to the impurity and want of heate in the urine it elfe, and outward cold extinguihing the internall heate, rarifying, dipering, and drawing out the pirits and naturall heate of the urine, which being diolved the urine waxeth troubled, thicke, and darke, Argent. 47. and this hath mall ignification in judgement of urines, aving in harpe dieaes it ignifieth beginning of concoction. Fernel. 450.
The other two kinds are darke when they are firt made. Dreggy urine, and confued urine.

2. Dreggy urine is, whoe ubtance of it elfe, or by ome internall mixture is thicke, and uch as come often from filthy and uncleane reines: and this by chafing at the fire or other heate, cannot be altered and made cleere, and hath many meates flying, floating, and wimming in
the urine, which by tanding ettle down to the bottome, and becommeth a thicke reidence, whereby the ret of the urine waxeth cleere. And this is like to wine troubled wirh mixture of dregges, uch commeth from the reines, or bladdder, troubled with humors, which urine bringeth forth with it new ulcer, blood: old ulcer, rotten, purulent, and filthy matter.
Thoe which bee troubled with ache in their reines, make uually uch urines through blood, matter, or other filthy impurity.

Veines abounding with groe humors, which naturall heate can carcely concoct, and o ome part is voided: hereof rie long dieaes, head-aches, preent or to come, and if it continue long lethargy or veternus.

Criticall evacuation uddenly made after long obtruction of the veines, liver, reines, pleene, in whole men after exercie, in ick men in declination of dieaes, epecially in long continuing agues, as quartane, and in dieaes of the liver, pleene, and breaking orth impotumes with eae of the patient.

Symptomaticall evacuation of humors raw, and uperfluous from the veines,
pleene, liver, as in jaundice, and o voiding with the urine, being in colour red or yellow, as in the beginning of continuall, and intermitting agues.

3. Confued urine is darke, wherein no moats are perceived to wim, or any other thing without ditinction, but the whole urine and every part thereof is all alike; neither by tanding etleth any reidence, or other thing to the bottome, whereby it may waxe clearer; and o continueth without alteration: yea, though it be chafed at the fire, and in warme water, and is like to wine which is changed and become dead with thunder, or with age is waxed owre or tart, without clearenee and brightnee, and this never rieth of dieaes in the reines, nor only of the inner parts, but alwaies commeth from dieaes of the veines, neither doth it ignifie abundance of raw humors, but properly confuion, putrefaction, and corruption, and that remedilee (malignam) of the bloud and humors in the greater veines: for putrefaction doth confound and huffle all things together: wherefore it is found onely in continuall, dangerous, and maligne agues. By thee I would have you to undertand that uch urine
(although it be not polluted with unclean reines) doth not alwaies hew the tate of the bloud and humors. For oftentimes it is yellow, thicke, and troubled, and yet the blood comming out of the veines by blood-letting is perfectly pure, and red, as it often chanceth in a quartane and tertian intermitting, as alo in the jaundice, when uperfluous choler doth ihue out of the liver, and gall, and other places, and falleth into the veines, and is not mixed with the blood, but onely with the urine: wherupon they are greatly deceived, which in thick and red urine do preently command blood-letting, as alo it happeneth many times, that the urine in colour, ubtance, and ediment is naturall, and yet blood let out is faulty, both in colour and ubtance: uch as are for the mot part in the tate, vigor, and before the critick day of continuall agues, when the urines are perfectly concocted, but the humor offending not at all, moved and voided. Fernel. 451. & 452.

div.head: CHAP. IV.
Of colours of Vrines.
div.p: COlours of urines are 21. which argue and hew crudity and concoction.

Crudity, both darke white, as milke white (Lacteus) as white of milke Horne-white, Glaucus, as the cleare part of a lanterne horne, Gray, Charopus, blandus color, like the white part of a mans naile next the joynt. But Galen aith, Charoppus is like the colour of Lyons eyes.
And light white, Chrytalline, Chrytallinus. Snowie, Niveus. Watery, Aqueus.
Concoction, but little or omewhat lacking, yet more then the former colours, pale, ubpiceus, ubpalidus, flaxen, piceus.
Perfect and abolute, bet, palew, or partly affron, ubrufus, ubaureus, ubulvus. Lighter then crowne gold, yellow as pure gold, Aureus. Actuar, Fulvus, rufus, Citrinus.
All degrees of colours following after yellow, doe ignifie heate. Sal. pag. 88. ex Avicon.
Exceeding the perfect and abolute concoction in thee degrees in heate. Salvian. 88.
1. Light affron (ubcroceus, ubflavus) like water wherein batard affron is diolved.
Saffron (flavus, croceus) like to water wherein the flower of affron is diolved.
2. Claret (ubrubeus, palmeus) like to bole armoniake.
Red (rubeus, puniceus) as red blood, cherries, red apples, affron it elfe.
3. Crimon (purpureus vineus) like blackih redde wine, liver colour, water wherein fleh new killed hath been wahed.
Purple (paeus, cyaneus) of the colour of raions of the unne, cherries waxing blacke, like wine boyled, Salvian. 81.
Blew (venetus, fucus, caeruleus, brunus, blavus) halfe white and halfe blacke mixed.
4. Greene (viridis, porracius, prainus) as leeke leaves, emeraude, coole-wort.
Oylie green (oleaceus) popinjay greene.
Ah colour, colour of lead (lividus plumbeus.)
Blacke (niger.)
¶In colours of urines we mut alwaies conider whether better ucceed wore or contrary, that o we may know the working of nature.

div.head: CHAP. V.
Of ubtance and colour ioyntly together.
div.p: THinne ubtance, joyned with colour white, privately without mixture of humours, as Snowe-water, or Chrytall ignifieth either crudity, obtruction or converion of the humor.

Crudity. Crudity through decay of naturall heate, and then the urine is made freely without paine, which commeth either by (Salv. 75.) Reolution of caue externall, great hunger, long fating, or watching, great exercie or labour, which if they be all moderate the urine is all more coloured and thicker, vid. cap. 1. under kinde of life. So in old men which by age are melancholike, and other cold conditions of the body. Argent. 25. ome large evacuation Sowning Weck

Or of caue internall, as the ill quality of the humor offending, maligne and petilent with other evill ignes. Or ele unnaturall heate overcoming the naturall heate, as fleh eething in a pot, being et in the unne is lee boiled the heate of the unne drawing out the heate of the water.

Such heate is in the whole body, in the beginning of dieaes, epecially agues, when unnaturall heate prevailing, the humors are raw and not concoct, and as in a conumption and lingring ague, the moiture of the body is reolved and moulten, which maketh the urine white, Aegid.

And in the reines and veels of urine, as in the piing evill (Diabetes) when through unnaturall heate and trength of the attractive faculty of the reines, urine is drawne too fat from the liver and tomacke before it can receive any ubtance and colour: and the retentive and digetive faculties of the reines, being feeble, and the expulive trong, the urine is preently voided often and much; whereupon followeth great thirt heate in the reines, wating of the body, cotivenee,
and if the griefe continue, death. Aegid.

Crudity through uffocation Or uffocation, and that either of caue externall, as eating or drinking immoderately, urfetting, quaffing, liberall feeding, mall exercie, urine made hortly after meat and drinke received, epecially much, or diuretike, whereby the urine is made before it be concocted in great and large quantity, without ubtance or colour.

Or of caue internall, as multitude of humors offending nature, moothering and choaking the naturall heate, as too much oyle extinguihing the Lampe, and too great quantity of greene wood the fire, as in all humorall dieaes before concoction appeareth, urine is white and thin, but after as the matter is concoct, and heate increaeth, urines vary. Wecker, uch as appeare in great cruditie of cold in children, a mortall igne. Salvian. 24.

Not a good igne in declination of a dieae, both for the ubtance and colour, but either heweth converion of the humor another way, or relape and reciduation, except the urine was made
afore in great quantity, for o it is a good igne. 31. Holler.
Dropie of cold ditemperature of the liver at the beginning, for afterward the matter increaing, the urine waxeth thicker.
Apoplexy.
Falling evill with leadih darke, and divere colour.
Swimming in the head with a certain greenih colour.
Palies.
Dieaes of flegme, want of appetite.
Dieaes of melancholy of his cold, and dry quality, but being voided in ubtance thicke and blacke. Aegid. 37.
Gout with little moats in the ediment.
Dieaes of the mother, whereunto womens cold contitutions are ubject.

Obtruction of ome parts of the body, Obtruction. in, neere, or about the paage of urine; as the liver, reines, water, conduits, the urine made with paine and little in quantity. Such obtruction arieth of melancholy, raw, groe, and indigeted, decending to the conduits of urine, as in a quartane with certaine rods or lines in
it, and rhe pleen ditent with melancholy maketh the paages of urine traight. Aegid.

Flegme groe and glay, decending to the water conduits, as in women flowers topped, and regurgitating to the veels of urine, with skales or blacke dut in the ediment, but ometimes blackih, and a red purulent matter.
Choler mixt with groy and clammy moiture, whereby it cannot ihue out with the urine, as in the jaundice ometimes.

Sand, gravell, as in the tone of the reines and bladder, partly topping the paages, as alo receiving nourihment, and increaed of tough, vicous lime, which otherwie would ihue with the urine, and make it thicker.
Slimy matter, as in the trangury.
Tumors, impotumes, growing either in the liver, or betwixt the reines and the bladder, or in places neere to the paages of urine, whereby they are made traighter.
Colicke or Iliate, the winde ditending the guts, and traitning the reines obtructing them, and continuing above even daies is mortall.

Co¯verion of the humors.Converion of the humor which hould give ubtance and colour another way, and o the veels of urine are more detitute of heate and humor, as to the braine in phrenies mortall, except there be other good ignes. Argent. 30.
To impotumes under the hort ribbes, arme-holes in the necke, about the privy parts.
To the pleene inflamed in ill igne. Weck.
To other parts of the body as before in thin urine. See there.
In all thee, if more coloured urines went before, and ceaing too uddenly and no evacuation ucceeded. Arg. 87. Actuar.
Milk white. Milke white hath the ame ignification as was before of now-water, eeing they differ not in kinde but in degree, but here is lee hurt, by reaon of better colour and tincture.
Health in harp dieaes, if the colour of gold went before.
Death, conumption of the lungs, if the colour of gold went not before, and accompanied with other bad ignes.
Pale flaxen Pale flaxen, the beginning of concoction.

Exulceration of the lungs and conumption
if it be little, and have leadih oily pale we; which is mortall with a laske.
Flegmaticke complexion in a young man being often made in thickih ubtance.
Palew, yellow, citrine Palew, yellow, citrine, in whole men perfect health, and if the ediment be good in young men, by comparion of this all other are to be judged.
Flegmaticke complexion if the ubtance be ome what thicke.
In icke men, hote and harp dieaes imminent.
In old men as a double tertian.
In children as a quotidian.
In young men flegmaticke, melancholike or crude contents if they continue long o, becaue their urine hould naturally be more remie for abundance of moiture.
Dieaes of the breat, the region full of bubbles.
Of the plene, when many rods or trikes appeare like meteors.
Of the liver if it be much in quantity, the body leane, the belly bound.

Light affro¯, affron. Light affron, affron, of caue externall, much watching, great labour and
travell, epecially in the heate of the Sunne, imple ditemperature of heate without mixture of humors, if it be pure and perpicuous, medicines purging choler, as Rheubarb, alo affron, cinnamon, broth of cherries.
Of caue internall, as choler abounding as in a tertian.
Ditemperature of humors, epecially blood if it be thickih darke.
Melancholike complexion in thicke ubtance, and cholericke in thin.
End of a icknee being made on the criticall day.
Blew, melancholy.
¶Vrines yellow, affron, red, do ignifie exceeding heate of imple ditemperature, if they be pure and perpicuous, but mixture of humor withall, if they be thicke and troubled, Fer. 447.
Thicke ubtance. Thicke ubtance joyned with colour.
White. White poitively with mixture of humors, betokeneth abundance of raw humors, flegme, glay, alt, unavory.
Conumption in a wating ague, o the fatty nourihment of the body, is molten and voided.
Impotumes breaking out, as in grievous agues, o rotten matter is voided, etling to the bottome and tinking, Salvian. 77.
End of an ague, if blood iue out of the noe, and being made on the judiciall day in great quantity, and then no impotume followeth.
Milk white. Milke white like water wherein a little meale is cat, is good in the end of an ague, and rather if great quantity of urine was made before, B. Holler.
Matter of the tone voided out of the reines and bladder, looke more in the ediment in raw humors and matter of a ore.
Flux of eed in a man or woman, carnall copulation if it be without corruption and tinketh not.
Dropie if the yellow jaundice continue through great crudity in the veines.

Horne white. Horne-white, like the horne of an old lanthorne, darke through moke, or gray, like the darke colour of an oxe liver, not troubled, betokeneth that the body is
full of groe humors, and flegmatike dieaes of the whole body if it be troubled, which is like a beats water, and o continuing long, or alwaies, yet ometimes being chafed at the fire, it cleareth when it is broken by cold ayre, ignifieth that the veines are full of ill humors, headache through agitation of humors acending. If it waxe cleare above, and cloddereth in the ediment, if it be much in quantity, then it betokeneth the end of an ague: if little in quantity, an ill igne in an ague.
All white urines ignifie ome good, if the patient be trong.
Claret. Claret, continuing of the dieaes, yet without danger, if it hath a ediment of like colour and ubtance.

Red like cherries. Red like cherries, or red apples, of caue externall, fore-heweth that the loynes or reines are beaten and bruied, or ome vein neer the reins open or broken, with paine in the place grieved, Actuar. receipt of ome purgation of rheubarbe, &c. as pag. 4. died with priver, Avicen. which Mont. 19. beleeveth not.

Internall, widenee, rarity, thinnee, or laxity of ome veines neere the reines, through which blood iueth, and weateth
out in great quantity, and weaknes of body, Actuar. the reines or bladder fretted, untill blood commeth, as in the tone, epecially after labour, with gravell.
Abundance of blood, as rotten agues epecially.
Abundance of choler, as in agues tertion, partly troubled with an uncleane and rough ediment, or emitertian with a leadih colour, and greene cloud.
Abundance of heate unnaturall, wating and melting the moiture of the body into urine made in great quantity, with fatte wimming aloft, as in a conumption.

Vrine taying too long in the body, being not provoked to iue either by harp quality, which lacketh in colde dieaes, or by great quantity being converted another way, and o at length by delay in the body, waxeth more coloured, and concoct: uch happeneth in the palie, apoplexy, epilepie, phtiicke, crampe, mortall, Haff. dropie mortall, or ele the liver through debility, is not able to eparate the blood from the urines, as in hepatica paione, Salvian. 87. Arg. 38.

Such alo happeneth in the laske, bloody flixe, Argent. 38. mortall, Haff.
cholike, iliake, mortall, Haffurt, paine in the reines, or ele to the place grieved, blood and heate are drawne, or ele choler not decending through the paage betwixt the liver, and the guts being obtructed with flegme, and winde, iueth with the urine, Aegid. 11.
Agues decaying, Fer.

Obtructions, inflammations cirrous tumors of the gall (being the naturall receptacle of choler) obtructed, the choler iueth at other parts, or ele that portion of choler, which hould be voided by tool, is here voided by urine, Argent. 37. as in the jaundie, with paine in the necke and hort ribs, and will colour a linnen cloath put into it.
Of the pleene, and liver, as in the dropie, o choler goeth to the urine.
Relape, or recidivation of the dieae, if it be made thicke, and traight after thin, before and after, the criticall day, becaue the heate which did at the firt expell the dieae now is overcome.
In young men without danger, with a good ediment through length of the dieae, but in old men death, not able to detaine the blood, Actuar.

Crimon. Chrimon betokeneth great labour and
travell in whole men, epecially in the heate of the Sunne or the fire, &c. wherby the blood is inflamed and roted, o in an ague.

Burning ague with thirt, watchings, cough, and other accidents of an ague, Actuar. Adution of choler and turning into melancholy, yet not o ill if there bee a good ediment: but ill, if the contents be ill or none at all, and the urine thicke, and groe like a cloud.

Purple. Purple betokeneth the yellow jaundice if it continue long, if there be ignes of concoction, it betokeneth health becaue the caue of the griefe is voided. Affection of the reines onely after Fer. and not of weaknee of the liver, whether the urine be red, bloody, or crimon, and like to the wahing of raw fleh, which Reu. miliketh.

Abundance of blood ometimes in young men, with ome heavinee or weight about the liver, and up to the chanell bone, or necke bone, and here it is not a very evill igne, but in old men very evill, yea often mortall, becaue they are not able through debility to detaine the blood.

Blew. Blew, beating, bruiing, tripes, where
it is a good igne, becaue the humor is voided. But Vaeus was deceived by a woman, mixing an oxe gall, Reunerus.
Extreame cold, and mortification, extinction of naturall heate, if the trength be weake, and no ignes of concoction beides.
Great exercie, and labour, great heate, and roting of the blood.
Melancholy ariing of a dut colour.
Changing of the bladder from his naturall dipoition in old men.
Strangury at hand in thoe that have the tone.
Recovery and health where the patient is mending in declination of the dieae, or being made on the criticall day.
Greene alone. Green or rather greenih, Argent. alone eldome of good hope, Mont.
Cold, extreme, mortall: if leadih colour and blacke follow ucceively at divers times, pule feeble, in thirt, or hort breath, Cappiv. 147. contrary to Reun. 136.
Quotidian ague, melancholy a dut, yellow jaundice epecially with an ague.

Heate and adution of humors a long time: if greene hath blacke immediately ucceeding, and not leadih comming
betweene, and accompanied with great heate in the body, thirt, ague, hort breath, and ome plendent glitring in the urine.
Green oyly Oyly, not uch wherein fat like piders webs floate, but uch whoe ubtance is clammy and thicke, as oyle or fat molten, and being haken is clammy and heavy as oyle, Fernel.
Good, if it be made only after black urine, as better ucceeding the wore.
Made on the criticall day, in great quantity, for o the matter is voided.
After paine of the reines without an ague, epecially appearing uddenly with great quantity.
Dropie, vehement cholike. This urine Galen hath often eene without any great hurt following, Cappiv. 92.

Ill, in a conumption of the body remedilee through great imbecility of the parts of the body riing of great ditemperature of heate, that they cannot containe nourihment, which voiding, doth give this colour to the urine. Reuner.
And in conumption of the lungs.
Tertian ague in fat and oft tender bodies, Argent.
Convulion of drinee, madnee, vomiting continuall thirt, heate, the tongue corched, &c. going before, yet if better colours follow, better hope, Actua.

Ah colour Ah colour leadih, good in beating, bruiings, if it ettle to the ediment, in blacke jaundice, becaue the caue of the griefe is evacuated. Ill, extreme and mortall heate in hot agues, if green colour was made before at other times. Contra Cappivac. 145. Epecially without ediment and other ignes of heate.
Mortall, trangury, following in a burning ague.
Extreme and mortifying cold, if the colour before was pale and other ignes of cold, Cappivac. 149.
The ame judgement is of blew colour, but that here all things are greater and augmented.
Blacke. Thicke ubtance with colour blacke, of caue either externall or internall.
Externall, eating of Caia, Argent. 40. &c. as before pag. 4. cap. 1.
Fall, bruiings, beatings, purgers of melancholy.

Internall by mixture of ome humor, as melancholy, blood adut, or choler
adut, Mont. 17.
Criticall evacuation with eae of the patient after great dieaes.
Quartane declining or rather burning ague, long or harp dieaes with bleeding at the noe and weat on the criticall day, els death, Actua. Child-birth, or with child, Cap. 151.
Womens flowers heretofore topped, and now voided if white or uch like went before.
Splenetike dieaes with a tumor in the pleene.
Chronicall dieaes of the backe and matrix of melancholy.
Melancholy, blacke jaundie, Wecker.
Madnee, fury, hemmoraudes.
Reines and bladder troubled with the tone, with tincke, by breaking ome little veines in the reines.
Other griefes of groe humors, but if there be great heate, paine, ague, want of appetite, a poie, ome dangerous canker, carbuncle, or naughty ulcers, Sal. 97.

Symptomaticall extreame and mortall, heate and adution, as in harp agues, if greene urine went before or red, with heate, leannee and thirt,
tinke of the urine and mall quantity, Cappiv. 111. 161. 169. Fern. Actuar. which may caue a dangerous cramp or convulion after great labour, except it be made on the criticall day.

Cold, if blew, green, or ah colour urine made before, with cold, and without tinch a little ediment, and united, Cappiv. 146. Selv. 94. but in this cae the urine is rather darke then blacke indeed, Mont. vide mercurial. varia. lect. lib. 2. cap. 11.
Blacke urines are mortall in all ages and perons, unlee they come of ome caue externall, or criticall evacuations, Salv. 93. 96. Cap. 157.

A generall note. ¶There be foure elementary qualities, whereof two be called active, and two paive: the active be heate, and cold, and thee give colour unto the urine: for heate maketh the urine red and tinct with high colours (which by moitnee are obcured and darkned, by drinee quickned & made far more lightome:) and cold maketh the colour of the water more remie, as white and uch like.

Now the two paive qualities, are moitnee and drinee, which caue ubtance in urines: whereof moitnee thickneth the urine, dulleth the colour, and
augmenteth the quantity: drinee clarifieth and ratifieth it, and that either by diminihing the quantity, contents, and ubtance, or by increaing the thinnee, clearnee, and brightnee thereof, with meane colour and groer ediment.

div.head: CHAP. VI
Of the quantity of Vrine.
div.p: Much quantity. QVantity of urine. Much of caue externall and internall.
Externall, moit, and rainy weather, and all things increaing moiture in the body, as leepe, idlenee, want of exercie, moit meates, or broaths, or other things which doe moiten the body.
Long and much drinking and quaffing of wine, water, color white, ubtance thin, Salv. 106.
Medicines diuretike which provoke urine, breake the tone, or make the urine harp and alt.

For by their heate they draw much urine, and by ubtilty of their parts they attenuate groe humors for expulion the
ediment being lender and glitering Actua. Salv. 101.
Internall evacuation, criticall or ymptomaticall.

Criticall, by trength of nature, eae of the patient, and other ignes of concoction as in dropie, anaarca, or great crudity, repletion of humors, when the humor hath been long hut up in a place and now findeth iue, Weck. Fern. o abundance of raw humors made thinner are voided by urine as Fernelius oberved, a drunkard, groe, fat, and well liking in 8. daies pace by continuall evacuation became lender and leane without any icknee at all.
Other dieaes colour, whither, ubtance thinner, ediment mean, and where thicke urine went before, ele not good except nature be trong, o in dieaes declining. Record.

Symptomaticall, through weaknee of nature without eae of the patient, and other ignes of crudity, as when the retentive faculty is decayed in dangerous dieaes, or nature is wearied, diolveth humors and voideth them uddenly by weat, toole, or urine, Actua. 116. as in laskes, flixes, want of appetite, chronicall
dieaes, convulion of heate and drinee in harp agues.

Conumption of the whole body omewhat fatty, in colour palew, reddih, high coloured, without ignes of concoction, for o the profitable fat, moiture, humors, and ubtantiall parts of the body are molten, diolved, and voided by urine. Sal. 109. Fern. 445.
Caue internall, heate of the liver drawing abundance of juice from the tomacke too fat, and not able to diget it.
Heat of the reines drawing the urine too fat from the liver and emulgent veines, peedily expelling it as in the piing ill, colour white, ubtance thin, ediment lacking, Actua.
Cold of the tomack breeding waterih juice, and ending it to the liver, for errour in the firt concoction is not taken away in the econd.
Cold of the liver not able to convert the profitable juice into nourihment, as in all habit of the body, dropie, anaarca, the urine waterih with raw and divere ediment, Bl. Hollerius.

Other excrements not evacuated either by toole, colour meane ediment
thicker and greater. Actuar. or by weat, or by pores of the skin, by inenible perpiration, &c. o the moit and thin parts are voided more abundantly by urine, o Arit. 4. de gener. animal. 4. reporteth a cow (whoe paunch-hole being hut up) had her excrements turned into winde and urine, Salv. 111.
Little quantity. Little of caue externall or internall.
Externall, as dry meats, colour palew, ediment mall and thicker.
Little drinking, tart, tipticke, thicke, or drying drinke.
Much weat, vehement exercie, or other things whereby the moiture of the body is dried and made lee.

Internall, veels of urine topped or obtructed by inflammation of the water conduits and necke of the bladder, tumor or welling, tough, groy, and clammy meates, as in the trangury, medicines, humors flegmaticke, tone, ee gravell in the ediment, with paine and griefe about the place affected. Dolor otendit locum, ee uppreion of urine.

Veels of urine hurt or weakened by old age, palie, ill ditemperature, or ome intrumentall dieaes of the parts whereby the urine cannot bee attracted, receireceived,
expelled, Salv. 113.
Internall caue, as tranlation of the urine another way, as to the belly, feet, and nether parts in the dropie.
To the guts in laskes, flixes, purgations ediment little, ubtance thin, color white and waterih, cap. 12.
To the Hemeraudes, mentruall evacuation of the flowers.
To the pores of the skin in weat and in enible perpiration.
Cods in the rupture, Hydrocele.
To the whole body, in the mall pocks, meails, impotumes, ee thin ubtance. And in recovery of health after icknee, o moiture is turned into nourihment of the body, Fer.
Internall caues, harp burning agues wating the moiture of the body, colour tending to blacke, Cappivac. 111.
Conumption of the body of long continuance whereby the moiture is dried, as in harp agues, conumption of the lungs, &c.
Meane quantity. Meane, proportionable to the drinke received the ame day, and other daies before, or omewhat lee, becaue ome is pent in the body, Health.

div.head: CHAP. VII.
Of the ignification of the contents of the Vrine in generall.
div.p: COntents are, whatoever is to be eene in the urine beide colour, ubtance, quantity, perpecuity, and darkenee, and they occupy ometime the top of the urine, as pume, bubbles, circle, ometime the highet part, or region (the whole urine according to his height being devided into three equall parts, which are commonly called regions) as the cloud (nubes.) ometime the middle region, as the ublation, or wimme: and latly ometime, and that mot often, the lowet region, or ediment; as gravell, blood, eed, dut, &c. as hereafter follow.
Contents are ometime lacking in the urine, and ometimes preent.

Contents wanting for five caues. Contents want in the urine for five caues. 1. For want of matter, which hould make the contents. As in great exercies, weat, inenible perpiration,
hunger, fating, laskes, purgations, either by vomite, or toole, emerauds, flowers, &c. alo in meats which increae choler, or cholericke dieaes.
2. Corruption of the matter, and humors in the body, whereby commeth neither nourihment nor excrement, Actuar.

3. Crudity, and lacke of concoction in whole men, by much quaffing, or thin, mall drinke, or by diuretike potions, which provoke urine. Alo piing hortly after drinking, before it receive any concoction, or mixture with meat, whereof contents come. In icke men, in whom, though humors doe abound, yet they doe not iue with the urine, but lurke in the veines, overloading nature, as in chronicall dieaes. Alo in harp agues in their beginning, or increaing great weakenee of nature, not able to expell the contents. And indeed in all humorall dieaes beginning, and increaing the contents are none at all, or little, becaue nature as yet hath made no concoction, or eparation, and in the tate of the dieae commonly contents are very few. But in declination, nature recovering her elfe, and prevailing againt the
dieae, the contents, cloud, wimme, and ediment alo returne, except in cholericke dieaes, where the cloud is ufficient, Cappivac. 67. 67. Alo in deficient agues beginning, the contents want, as in a tertian, in thicke ubtance, and yellow colour: but if ah colour, death followeth. In a quartane the urine is thin, and white. In a quotidian, thin, white, and waterih.

4. Converion of the humor another way, as, in impotumes, in cold weather, weake bodies, and injudicable tate of the dieae. In inflamations, which draw the contents and humors to them. In parts weake, or grieved whether humors fall, as before in thin urine. Looke there cap. 2 pag. 13. 14.
5. Obtruction in white, and thin urines with ignes of concoction, or without crudity. See cap. 2. pag. 13. 14.

¶Lee to be dipraied, if the colour and ubtance bee good, according to which, the humor abounding, trength of nature, and quantity of the dieae are to be judged, as before in ubtance and colour, Actua. 94. But dieaes of choler are ended if the cloud onely appeare. But in flegmatike, and of repletion the ediment
preent mut argue their diolution, Capiv. 67. 164.

Contents ometimes good and omtimes ill. ¶Contents appearing in the urine are of two orts: for they are either partly naturall, partly unnaturall, ometimes good and ometimes ill. Or ele, they be altogether unnaturall, and alwayes ill.
In contents which are partly naturall, partly unnaturall, we conider (as in the whole urine before) colour, ubtance, and quantity.

div.head: Colour of the Contents.
div.p: White. White duely knit, or hanging together equally, ignifieth good concoction in the liver, and veines, health, rule of all other.
Not equally knit, but thicker in one part then in another, ignifieth weak digetion, crudity, windinee.

White not duely knitte or hanging together, but ragged, tattered and broken aunder equally, crudity, windinee. Not equally, but thinner in one place then in another, ignifieth the falling evill, windinee, groe humors abounding in the body, meails, or mall pockes, where the colour waxeth red.
White as now; ignifieth flegmaticke humors and crudities.
Pale.Pale, flaxen, blood turned into choler and evacuated.

Saffro¯, &c. Light affron, affron, red, claret, ignifie crudities, alo blood thin and waterih, yet wherein concoction is to bee looked for hortly. Alo choler abounding in icke perons, Reun. 178. Continuance in tertian and quotidian agues epecially batard. A good igne in agues, which rie of abundance either of blood or ill humors, in which the ediment is neceary before recovery can be looked for. But in agues caued through heate of the Sun, much labour, or hunger, the wimme or cloud is ufficient to ignifie recovery of health, although the ediment doth not appeare. ¶For reddih looke ubtance following.

Bloody. Blood, like to the wahing of raw fleh, ignifieth abundance of blood. Or ele flux of blood iuing out, as out of ome veine broken. But yet we mut not be haty in judgement by this colour, but rather looke after under the title of pure blood voided, Reun. 181. Alo it ignifieth imbecility, or obtruction of the liver, which cannot concoct the blood, and o it runneth to the bladder.

Blew. Blew, leadih, ignifieth naturall heate
extinguihed or mortified, and therefore great danger.
Greene Greene blackih ignifieth great exceeding heate, or conumption and pining away.

Blacke. Blacke ignifieth either great cold, if leadih colour went before, and then the outward parts are cold, Salvian. 128. or great heate if greene colour went before, and then heate, thirt, and other tokens of heate accompany it. Both thee are mortall, as you may ee in thicke ubtance and blacke colour.
Or ele blacke contents ignifie melancholike dieaes, or melancholy, critically evacuated: where it is a good ign of health becaue the humor is voided.
If ignifieth alo conumption of the reins with an ague, the ediment oyly and fatty, Reun. 188.
Latly, it ignifieth beating, bruiing, tripes, and o come corrupt, blacke, and rotten blood is voided.
Subtance of the contents is either mean, thick or thin.
Meane. Subtance meane, is a good igne of health, becaue it is according to nature.

Thicke. Thicke contents generally ignifie groe, and raw humors much abounding
or imbecility of the econd concoction.

And in dieaes beginning, and increaing an ill igne, becaue they ignifie abundance, and trouble of humors before naturall heate hath concocted, and attenuated them. But in dieaes declining a good igne, if the colour, and other ignes be good, nature being now of trength to make eparation, and expulion of humors.

Thicke contents, and of colour claret, ignifie abundance of blood, or good and trong operation in digetion, Reuner. 203. but contents of colour blacke, ignifie great tore of blood, and the more blacke, the greater adetion of blood, Reuner. 204.

Thin. Thin contents which doe not eaily arie, nor trouble the urine, when the urinall is haken and moved, Reuner. 186. ignifie raw humors, or want of heate in the econd concoction in whole men. But in dieaes riing of cold, or ill juice, thin ubtance, heweth great danger. Becaue naturall heate is choaked, and oppreed, that it cannot expell the humour offending. Contrariwie in harp dieaes, or in dieaes which rie of imple and bare ditemperature without mixture of
humors. They are not very ill, eeing humors are not the caue of the dieae, which voiding with the urine, hould make the contents thicke.
If the ediment lightly arie, the urinall being haken, it argueth more heate, Va. 71.
¶If they continue either thicke, or thin, they ignifie weaknee of nature, which hould change them, Argent. 71.

div.head: Quantity of contents is either much, little, or meane.
div.p: Much. Much ignifieth. 1. Lacke of ufficient heate to attenuate and concoct the groer parts o in winter, drunkards, leepers, idle perons, women and children contents are moe, Reun. 64.
2. Much nourihment, good and trong digetion.
3. Other evacuations uppreed, as ordure, weat, &c. and epecially in flegmatike bodies, which are grieved with ome dieae, which will end well.
Little or few contents.Little.

1. Want of matter, as in hunger, great heate, ummer, luty age, great exercie, quartane and quotidian agues beginning for want of heate, Argent. 72. but afterwards
much. Contrary in tertians.
2. Obtructions and toppings of the emulgent veines, water conduits, reines, bladder, &c. Salvia. 120. As in thin urine ee there.
3. Crudity and low concoction.

4. All caues which doe attenuate and make thinner any matters in the body, that o the thinner part may evaporate out, and the groer tay within, and make obtruction, alo all caues which do wat and conume the body.
Meane. Meane contents of good ignification becaue they are according to nature.

div.head: CHAP. VIII
Of contents in peciall.
div.p: OF deformed contents, altogether unnaturall, and alwayes ill; which appeare either in the ediment or lowet region, or in the wim or middle region, or latly in the cloud or upper region. And firt of unnaturall and deformed contents in the ediment, which are commonly reckoned fifteene.

Popinjay greene. 1. Popinjay greene or oyly ediment
ignifieth.
Colliquation of the whole body, with paine, an ague, and pied lowly by little and little: or ele collaquation of the reines or bladder onely with paine in the reines, no ague, and pied fat.
Spider webs. 2. Spider webs or fatnee wimming in the urine, ignifieth
Conumption of the whole body with an ague.
Red vetches. Red vetches or fitches, ervaceum, orobeum, ignifie
1. Great inflammation of the liver.
2. Colliquation of the whole body: or of the reines onely, with conditions as before in popinjay greene.
4. Plates, cales, (folium, laminae, quamae) having bredth and length onely, like cales of fihes, epecially a gogeon.
Plates, cales. 1. Conumption or colliquation of the whole body, with an ague, low piing, tinch, and crudity in the ret. All concurring together.
2. Exulceration of the bladder, pied thicke and fat, with tinke, purulent matter, paine, and concoction, Salvian. 176.
3. Inflammation of the bladder or liver.
5. Groe and coure branne, Furur.
Thin. 1. Conumption of rhe whole body with crudity and thin urine.

2. Scabbednee of the whole body, without ague or other paine, Hafur, or of the bladder onely, with concoction, no ague. And paine of the bladder, thicke and tinking, an itch about the root of the yard, and purulent matter was pied before, Salv. 175.
3. Great heate wating the ubtance of the liver, and burning the blood, if the bran be red.

6. Fine bran, fine meale or flower (imila, Fine meale puls,
< in non-Latin alphabet > .)
1. Colliquation of the ollid parts, if they be white.
2. Extreame adution of the blood, if they be red, and therefore long icknee, Salvian. 179.
3. Sharp icknee, and for the mot part mortall.

4 Women with childe have fine meale or tarch in the wimme, or etling to the ediment of their urine, like fine carded wooll, the ret of the urine a little troubled, and greenih, or ah colour, Fernel. Looke motes in the ediment.
7. Raw humor (crudus humor) clammy but not tinking like nevill of the noe, or white of an egge.
Raw humor. 1. Exulceration of the reines and bladder without paine.
2. Impotume or tone of the reins and bladder with paine.

3. Multitude of raw humors omtimes cauing an ague, and appearing in the ediment, ignifie ache in the reins, ciatica, gout, trangury, tenamus. In the wimme, crudity and windinee in the tomacke, with a noie, and vomiting. In the cloud, griefe in the pirituall parts, hortnee of winde, purivenee, pitting of blood, Hacfur. Aegid.
4. Eating of meats hard to diget, in ore labouring men, Va. 74, 75.
8. Rotten and purulent matter. Matter of a ore (pus) tinking, but not much clammy, which when the urinall is haken, dipereth it elfe into fatty and oyly reolutions, and ignifieth,

Rotten matter. 1. Exulceration of the reines without paine, Fernel. of the bladder with paine about the bladder. Of the liver with paine under the right hort ribs, and doth not alwaies tinke liver putrefied, if it be very dreggy, Aegid. 69.
2. Inflammation or impotume of the lungs, whoe purulent matter paeth by the left cavity of the heart into the great artery, and thence into the emulgent veins, and o to the reines.

3. Plurifie, whoe matter paeth as before. As alo by the veine without a fellow ( < in non-Latin alphabet > ) riing on the right ide of the hollow veine, neere the heart and by the backbone, nourihing eight ribs on either ide: and o to the midriffe, and at length by divers turnings into the left emulgent veine, and thence to the reine.

4. Rhewme, which if it be thick, comming to the bladder it maketh difficulty in piing by drops. 5. Alo the phrenie. 6. or quinie, whoe purulent matter of thee three is conveyed through the jugular veines into the hollow vein, and thence into the emulgent veines, and o to the reines, if there be paine and griefe in the lungs, liver, bladder, in thee griefes aforeaid, otherwie if purulent matter be voided, and no paine in thee members, it is certaine that nature voideth it riing of inflammations. 7. or venerous and contagious flux of eed, Fernel.

9. Haires like pieces of fleh, long, lender, and hairy) poli, carunculae, filamenta)
onely in thicke urine, Salvian. 182. and ignifie.

Haires or filaments. 1. Diolution of the whole body, with an ague, colour oily or greene, Hasfurt. or of the reines onely without an ague, the haires fatty and groe, and may bee felt betwixt the fingers, like a mall, lender, flehy ubtance.
2. Obtruction of the reins, with groe and clammy humors, as in the trangury, dyury, piing ill, &c. with nummednee of that foot, which is on the ame ide the reine is, right left.
3. Exulceration of the reines or bladder, whence commeth purulent matter.
4. Flux of eed after carnall copulation, venerous pollutions on the night: or filthy and exulcerate gonorrhea, Fernel.
5. Womens white flowers iuing, or women having uncleane matrices, Fern.
10. Gravell and, (Arenula, abulum) red, white, or duskih browne, ignifieth.

Cravell and. 1. Stone breeding or diolving either in the reines, if the gravell be red, (yet ometimes white by filth incloing the gravell, Fernel.) and paine about the reines in the backe, no ague, and the gravell being taken out of the urinall and dried in a hadowie
place, are hard in touching. Or in the bladder if the gravell be white and pain in the bladder, about the hare where the haire groweth.

¶Yet thoe men whoe paages of urine are wide and open, and expulive faculty trong, and making uch andy urine freely, and without paine, in good quantity, are eldome troubled with the tone, becaue their reines and bladder are hereby clened, and the gravell not uffered to tay o long to unite and gather together to make the tone, but uch gravell doth argue great heate of the liver or reines, and abundance of raw and groe humors fit to breed the tone, if the paages of urine hould be obtructed, or expulive faculty, weakened, Salv. For abundance of tough and vicous uperfluities, traitnee of paage, and weakenee of the expulive faculty, are three epeciall caues of the tone, Aegid.

A profitable hitory of the tone. ¶But leat the contents mixed with urine, which for the mot part come from the veels of urine, hould deceive him that would rightly judge of other parts of the body, I will repeat the whole caue, and order of the effects from the
beginning. Red gravell come from the reines, which being many, and thicke doe threaten the tone, of thoe growing together, groweth a tone as big as a graine of millet, or barley corne, which being extruded out of the ubtance of the reines, into a larger place, doth make the urine thicke, troubled, red, or blackih, a forerunner of the dieae of the reines, the ame being thrut into the head of the water pipe (ureter) caueth great paine, and then the urine is white and thinne as in obtructions, the ame growing bigger, is ometimes o fatned in the reines, that it cannot be removed, and then after great labour and exercie by fretting of the reines with the tone, the urine is not onely thicke, and troubled, but alo bloody, and ometime clods of blood etled downe: uch urines are ometimes made after a fall, or beating, and eldome after great labour: when the ulcer is thus made, in ret, and quietnee, the urine is thicke, and white: after labour more coloured, with a thicke ediment: after that the urine is thicke, white, and tinching, and purulent, not much unlike milk in which purulent matter etleth, when as the ulcer is hollow and
filthy; uch urine hinder judgement of all other parts of the body, ave the reines, and when as the ulcer groweth very filthy, and commeth to a fitula in this white, thicke, troubled, and tinking urine, oftentimes a thicke, limy, tough matter, like the nevill of the noe, or white of an egge etleth, and uch oftentimes iueth when the tone is in the bladder, for though the matter thereof commeth from the reines, yet it groweth and wrappeth about the tone through fault, or weaknee of the bladder, which may appeare, for that the urine continueth o when the tone is voided: moreover filthy ulcers of the necke of the bladder, and yard, and fluxe of eed in the French dieae, doe caue uch urines: but at the firt certaine lender filaments appeare, then more groe, whereof the whole urine waxeth thicke, and latly this filthy ediment that now we peake of. And although the ulcer be cured, yet certain filaments remaine through imbecility of the bladder, and permatike veels, Fernel. 455.

2. Adution of humors. As in dieaes of choler, as burning agues, Salvian. 183. tertian agues, ingle and compound.
Alo in dieaes of melancholy, as quartane ague long continued. Gout after long drying and thickning of the humor. Paine of the joynts and reines. Leproie, morbus Gallicus confirmed, emeraudes cotivenee, Aegid. Alo heate of the liver, if there be no paine nor heavinee about the reines.A gr • vell note againt uch and. ¶Such andy gravell floteth in the whole body of the urine, like motes in the Sunnebeames, and after etling to the ediment, covering the bottome of the urinall, or in colour browne, or duskih red, and cleaveth to the ides of the urinall, and being dried in a hadowie place are omewhat oft and tractable. Looke after for gravell in the wimme.
3. Receipt of harp diuretike medicines which provoke urine, which skouring the reines, doe bring uch gravell with them.
Wormes. 11. Wormes, little dragons. (vermes, dracunculi.)
1. Putrefaction, whereof they be engendred, Argent.

12. Blood, pure, thicke, groe, or cloddy, (anguis, grumus anguinis) when the veels of blood and urine
have their

Blood, clods of blood. 1. Orifice opened ( < in non-Latin alphabet > ) wherby blood iueth, either becaue that the blood exceedeth in quantity, as in anguine men. Or in criticall evacuation, though eldome, o womens flowers voiding by urine are groe and cloddy, etling to the ediment, and no paine in any part of the body. So in declination of dieaes of the pleene, with much reidence and dregs, Hasfurt. Or ele when the blood exceedeth in quality, as when it is too thin, harp, or alt, tickling the veels, and provoking them to expulion. Or ele when the veels of blood and urine are either too large, wide, and open, as the veines emulgent carrying the urine from the hollow veine to the reins, being too open, doe receive blood from the hollow veine, Wecker. Or when the aid veels are too weake in their retentive faculty; as when the veines be too weake, o in the mall pockes (exanthemata) blood taied in other places, and overloading nature, is voided by urine, which if it tinke, and the pocks be blew or leadih, mortall. Or the liver too weake, o pure blood is voided by toole, or urine, as the hollow or round part of the
liver is affected, with paine under the right hort ribs, and tinketh not. Ha. or the hollow veine too weake, o pure blood is voided with paine about the eventh joynt in the backe, from os acrum upward. Aegid. Or latly, the reines and bladder too weake and feeble, as in old men at the pits brinke.

2. Membranes or tunicles of the veines, laxe, thin, and full of pores, o thin, watery, and warme blood running between the skinne and the fleh, weating out ( < in non-Latin alphabet > ) in procee of time gathereth together into blacke and leadih clods.

3. Subtance and membranes hurt ( < in non-Latin alphabet > ) by a fall, beating, bruiing, leaping, violent exercie, great burdens, o cloddy blood voideth. Or by medicines, which are corroives and cautickes or openers of obtructions, or by the tone in the reines or bladder after exercie: o the reines or bladder being wounded and exulcerated, filthy and cloddy blood voydeth with tinke and paine about the places grieved. Dolor otendit locum. Record.

¶If blood iue by any of thee wayes in the veels of the lungs, breat, arteries,
tomacke, belly, or guts, there followeth vomiting of blood; but in other parts by the two firt waies, it gathereth into clods. Ianus Cornarius in Gal. lib. &
< in non-Latin alphabet > , 74.
13. Seed (perma, emen) which lightly floteth and acendeth, the urinall being haken. And iueth with the urine either for that the

Seed. 1. Seed aboundeth in quantity, as after carnall copulation, deire of carnall copulation, or venerous dreames, &c. Or when the eed in quality is either too harp, hot, or alt, then the yard is extended, and iueth with ome delight in good quantity, and tinketh, Wecker in gonorrhaea.
