Or when the eed is too thin or waterih, which iueth without ene almot and unwillingly, the yard not extent, and then the whole body waxeth leane, epecially the loines. Or latly, when the eed is virulent and contagious, as in morbo gallico, with tinch of the urine, and ometime gravelly or andy contents.

2. Veels permatike are either too lippery; or ele weake in their retentive faculty, with wating of the whole body, as in Apoplexy, palie in the genitours,
falling icknee. For in thee dieaes, toole, urine, feed, &c. are involuntary.
Dut. 14. Dut, (cineres) black or leadih and heavy, like a blacke pouder riing of melancholy, and ignifieth,
1. Fluxe of the emeraudes preent or hortly to follow, the colour of the urine remie. And ometime vomiting of blood.
2. Paine and dieaes of the pleene, epecially after purging of melancholy. The dut being omewhat browne or purple.

3. Stopping of the flowers. In ubtance, thicke, colour pale, flaxen, or white, ediment little or lacking. And ometime vomiting of blood, and the dut gathered and heaped together in the ediment or bottome.
4. Paine in the reines, loines, and other inferiour parts, by which the melancholike blood paeth in the hemorrhoidall veines to the eat.
15. Motes (Atomi) uch as appeare in the Sunne-beames, little and round, red or white, little flockes. And thee appearing in the urine ignifie,
1. Putrefaction as in the plague,Motes. morbus gallicus, with tinch.
2. Great agitation and commotion of the humors, as in the mall pockes and meails.

In thee two the motes flote all over the urine yet warme, and during t • e naturall heate thereof; and after etling to the ediment, doe ignifie a doubtfull trife betwixt nature and the dieae, to be decided by age, trength of the patient, and other ignes, Montan. 50.

3. Rhewme in the whole body, if the aid motes doe appeare in the whole urine. Or in the uperiour parts of the body onely, if they appeare onely in the upper region of the urine. Or in the middle parts of the body, if they appeare in the middle region. Or latly, the lowet part of the body, if they appeare onely in the lowet region or ediment of the urine, the motes are rough and the urine troubled.
4. Gout with conditions, as before in rhewme.
5. Dieaes of the mother.

6. Conception in women, etling down to the ediment, which if they be red, through greater abundance of heate and
blood, a male childe is conceived. If white through lee abundance of heate and blood, a female is conceived.

div.head: Moe ignes of Conception.
div.p: Becaue Phyitians vary in judgement, what urines doe ignifie conception (yea Io. le. Bon. in his treatie de therapeia puerpurarum. Foretus in his booke de incerto & falaci urinarum iudicio, lib. 2. cap. 3. and divers others, doe deny that any certaine judgement thereof can bee gathered by urine.) I thought good therefore not onely to et downe their everall opinions thereof by urine, but alo adde moe igns beides urine. Both generally of conception, and pecially whether it be of male or female.

div.head: Signes of conception by urine.
div.p: Divers opinions about womens conception. 1. Generally womens urine with child is lee concoct, white, thin, with a little ediment, yet the nearer they draw to childebirth, it waxeth more coloured.

2. Some ay there appeareth in the urine, like fine flower or tarch, which after the urine is etled, hath a edimentor wim omewhat thicke, like fine carded wooll, and the ret of the urine troubled, and omwhat greene or blacke.

3. Other hold that their urine is white with a cloud, wimming aloft, and many motes floting in the whole urine, uch as are in the Sunne-beames and epecially in the firt moneth; and when the urinall is haken or moved they depart aunder, like carded wooll. In the moneths following, the urine is red or yellow, and at length blacke, with a red cloud wimming aloft.

4. Other ome take their judgement by the ediment only, which they affirme is like cotten or fine carded wooll; or raw ilke. Reuner thinketh that they bee little flockes or motes, &c. as before in motes.

div.head: Other ignes of conception, beides the urine.
div.p: 1. The tearmes are taied without grief after they have iued eight or ten dayes after copulation.
2. They feele a wringing, beating, and moderate paine about their navill, wombe, loynes, tomacke, backe, and thighes.
3. Their appetite to meat omewhat decayeth, yet longeth after trange things which affection is called Citta or pica, Aegid. 74.

4. They have ometime bitter belchings, vomitings, hardnee of the paps, and rednee of the teates, welling of the veines and arteries, epecially within the noe and eyes, paine, or wimming in the head, dimnee of ight, red pimples in the face, cotivenee, no deire of copulation, though before they had great delight.

5. If a very cleane needle be put into a womans urine with childe in a braen baon all night, and on the morrow be coloured and died with red pots, he hath conceived: but if it be blacke and ruty, he hath not.
6. If after upper going to bed, he drinke water and honey odden together (Hydromel) and feele a wringing in her guts he hath conceived, ele not, Hippoc. 5. Aphori. 57.

div.head: Speciall ignes of conception whether it be of male or female.
div.p: Whether male or female. 1. Motes in the ediment red and round, ignifie a male: but motes white and round, a female.

2. Milke (in conception of male) commeth ooner into her breats, which being milked, and et in a glae in the Sunne, it
waxeth hard into a tone, not unlike a bright pearle.
3. All her right ide is better and more luty then her left, right eye fairer, right pap greater with milke, the pule of her right artery wifter.
If milke be cat upon the womans water with childe, it will ink to the bottome, neither will it depart aunder, though alt be cat in.

4. If a womans urine be kept three days in a glae bottle topped, and after train it through a fine, cleane linnen cloath, if there appeare, little quicke living creatures, and red, a male is conceived, if white a female.
6. Tearmes flow after the fourteenth day, and the childe is felt to tirre, and move after the fifty day. To be hort, all things are more quicke, luty, and trong in the male, then in the female, Reun.

And to be hort, becaue the eed of the male is hotter and livelier then of the female, therefore all things in the male are ooner performed, as the male receiveth all the lineaments of his body, and perfect hape of a man in his mothers wombe in thirty dayes: the female
in forty. The male beginneth to tirre in the wombe in three moneths: the female in foure. The male is borne and commeth forth of the wombe in nine moneths, the female in ten. And the mother her elfe after birth of a male, hath forty daies aigned for her purification; but after the birth of a female, fourecore daies, Levit. 12. 4, 5. And that men are hotter in contitution then women, may eaily appeare in that they have fewer excrements, larger veines, blacker colour, greater and lutier members, greater voice, more audacity and courage then women, Bertinus.

div.head: Contents in the middle region of the urine.
div.p: Contents in the middle region or wimme The middle region of the urine, ublation, or wimme, ( < in non-Latin alphabet > ) is the middle ditance of the urine divided into three equall parts: and here, (as before in contents in generall, and in the ediment in peciall) are conidered.

Colour, ubtance, quantity, contents, &c. All which have the ame ignification for the mot part, as before in the ediment,
ave in thee ixe differences following.
1. Contents in the wimme, ignifie ome windinee, whereby they are elevated o high.

2. Good contents in the wimme, which ignifie health (as white, affron, claret, light, and equall) are not o good as in the ediment, yet in agues of choler, heate of the Sunne, hunger, labour, anger, &c. Preence of the wimme, is a ufficient igne of health, but of flegme or melancholy, (which are not o oone concocted) the preence of the ediment is neceary before there can be any ecurity of recovery, Cappivaccius, 67.
3. Ill contents in the wimme, which are ignes of icknee, as blacke, greene, leadih, olide, and deformed contents, are not o ill, as in the ediment, Cappivac. 171.

4. Contents in the wimme give ignification of the affections and dieaes in the middle parts of mans body, as about the hort ribs, hypocondria, inward entrals, as the pleene, liver, heart, lungs, bowels, &c. vicera, bret, tomacke. Va. 81. As alo contents in the cloud, ignifie
dieaes of the highet part of mans body, and the ediment of the lowet parts. Yet divers milike this application of the three regions of the urine, to the three parts of mans body, Aegid.

5. Sand or gravell, (not in the ediment, but in the wimme) in colour reddih, and ticking to the ides of the urinall, as though the urine hould thicken, or congeale into tones, ignifieth Adution of the liver, Va. 90.

6. Motes (Atomi) floting through the whole urine, and being elevated and puffed up by unnaturall and flatuous heate, and after it be cold, etling to the ediment, or troubling the urine, ignifieth a great trife in the veins, betwixt naturall heate and the dieae, to be determined by age, trength, diet, complexion, and good order of the patient, Mont. 50.

div.head: Of the cloud or uppermot region of the Vrine.
div.p:
Cloud. The highet or uppermot region of the urine (being as I aid before divided according to his height, into three equall parts) is called the cloud (nubes,
< in non-Latin alphabet > ) wherin we conider (as in the two former
regions, ubtance, quantity, colour, contents, &c. which have the ame ignification as before: ave that contents here in the cloud, compared with other regions, have leat ignification of good, in good ignes: and contrary, leat ignification of ill, in ill ignes.

div.head: Colours of the Cloud.

list.head: White.White.
list.item: 1. Not of very evill ignification, becaue all contents are naturally white.
2. In perfect tertian agues abundance of choler, and o continuance of the dieae.
3. In rotten agues (ynochus) great danger through pain and griefe in the forepart of the belly about the hort ribs, Reuner. 236.

list.head: Red.Red.
list.item: 1. Changing of the icknee into a quartane.
2. Concoction of humors, beginning to be on the eventh day or criticall day, if this red colour appeare on the fourth day or judiciall day.
3. Head-ache, through winde and flatuous pirits acending up into the head, and o continuance of the dieae.

div.p:
Blacke.Blacke.
Long watchings, and lacke of leepe whereof followeth the lightnee of the braine, raving, doting, which in old men is mortall.

div.head: Deformed contents in the cloud.
div.p: Deformed contents of the cloud are of three orts, according to the places which they occupy, for 1. either they appeare in the whole region of the cloud. 2. or occupy onely the edge, ring or circle round about the urine. 3. or latly they lote all over the top of the urine. And to begin with the firt.

div.head: Deformed contents appearing in the whole region of the cloud are three.
div.p: White cloud. 1. Little white cloud (nebula) ignifieth flegmatick matter to be elevated by trong heate, and for the mot part, a good igne and ignification of concoction, and which will hortly, as the dieae declineth, etleth down to the ediment, by orderly proceeding of nature.

Smoake. 2. Smoake, in colour, blackih, reddih, or yellow, ignifieth vicous and tough matter adut, cholericke. Abundance of unnaturall heate, puffing up, and elevating ome raw matter, and therefore continuance
of harp dieaes not without danger.

3. Small graines, kernels, droppes or motes dipered, ragged (granula divula) which if they appeare neere to the top of the urine, epecially if they be blackih, they ignifie adution of the matter, and wating of the olid parts, as alo that they are violently puffed up by unnaturall heate of maligne agues, which oftentimes are mortall, Mont. 51.
Deformed contents appearing in the circle round about the urine, commonly called the crowne (corona) which ometime is wanting, and ignifieth,
Equall conflict betwixt nature and the dieae.
The crowne appearing round about the urine ignifieth generally.
1. Some windinee, wherof the crown is made.
2. Affections and griefes of the head.
3. If the colour of the crowne differing from the ret of the urine be better, it is a good igne, that nature overcommeth, but if it be wore an ill igne, that nature is overcome.

The placing of the urinall, and difference of the ight, may caue divers colours
in the crowne, becaue it coniteth indifferently in the confines or common concure of three divere tranparent mediums (media) the urinall, the urine, and the aire; and therfore the colours of the crown may be variable according to the divere poition of the urinall, the urine, the aire, and the eye of a Phyitian beholding it. Like other apparent and not permanent colours, which are made of divere mixture of light and darke. (Lucidi & umbroi) as colours of the rainbow, of a Doves neck, a Peacockes taile, changeable taffety, and morning clouds lightened with the Sunne-beames, infinitely variable, according to their divere poitions and placings, taught in the precepts of optikes. Therfore Actuarius counell is, to looke into rhe crowne with one eye.

div.head: Colours of the crowne.
div.p: Leadih. 1. Leadih, blew, and blacke, ignifie the falling icknee, or mortification of the braine, whereby the inewes doe not their duty in ene and motion.
2. Firt leadih, then red certaine daies after, ignifieth head-ache, or recovery of the animall power.

Greene. 3. Greene ignifieth choler greene
like leekes (porracea) or phrenie of green choler, if it be in a harp ague: or adution of hot choler aaulting the head.
4. Black is of the ame judgement that blacke water is of. For it ignifieth mortification, if leadih colour went before: or adution, if greene.
Thicke crowne joyned with colours.
Saffron. 1. Saffron ignifieth choler in the head, and head-ache thereof.
White. 2. Waterih and white, flegme in the hinder part of the head.

Claret. 3. Claret, or crimon, abundance of blood in the head, pricking paine of the temples, fulnee of the veines, and the patient uppoing himelfe to ee little red motes flying before his eyes. Or head-ache through abundance of blood.
Thinne crowne joyned with colours.
Flaxen. 1. Flaxen, ignifieth ache in the left ide, of the head of melancholy. Or the head, to be of cold and dry contitution. Or melancholike complexion, and therefore upicious, fearefull, covetous.
Yellow. 2. Yellow, head-ache of choler pricking in the ide of the head.

Crowne trembling, haking, quivering,
ignifieth
Crowne trembling. 1. Paine all along downe the backebone.
2. Windinee.
3. Thin humor.
4. Stopping of the flowers. Deformed contents floting in the top of the urine; either in the crowne, or all over the top, as pume, froth, bubbles, droppes of oyle, or droppes of fat like pider-webs.

Fome froth bubbles. Fome, froth, bubbles, is an extenion, welling, or puffing up of a vicous moiture in a thicke and groe vapour thorough agitation: either of heate, as in water eething. Or motion, as in the ea. Or both, as in running waters. In urine they are made as Montanus thinketh, of naturall or unnaturall heate rarefying and diipating, ome tough, vicous, and flegmie matter in the veines reiting, whereupon the heate not finding ready iue, doth puffe up and extend it, making froth or bubbles. But Argenter miliketh this opinion for that, in batard agues, quotians, and tertians, where both flegme and unnaturall heate abound, which might tirre and puffe it up, and yet froth doth not alwayes accompany thee agues.
Therefore hee thinketh that froth in the urine, is alwayes caued of motion, and gives ignification of rhewmes and detillations, decending from the head into the inferiour parts, &c. They appeare in the urine, being caued either of caue externall, or internall.
Externall caue of fome, froth, and bubbles.
Externall caue. 1. Eating of pule or fruit, urfetting, Fernel.
2. Piing with ome violence into the urinall.
3. Shaking of the urinall, Aegid. 68. Salvian. 144.
Internall caue.Internall caue of fome froth, or bubbles, wherein are conidered (as in other contents) colour, quantity, ubtance, time of their appearance, and their differences.

div.head: Colour of the fome, froth, and bubbles.
div.p: Divere. 1. Divere. Signifieth crudity, Aegid. 68.
White. 2. White. Raw and flegmaticke matter.
Saffron. 3. Saffron. Iaundice. But mixed with ome whitenee in the middle, dieaes of the lungs.
4. Leade colour or blackih,Leadih. matter adut.
Blacke. 5. Blacke. Extinction of naturall heate.

div.head: Quantity of the fome, &c.
div.p: Much. Much, many, or thicke together, long continuing, and carcely to be abolihed with a rods end, wrapped about with flax and put into the urine, Aegid. 66. and ignifieth
In whole men. Some tough and vicous matter which naturall heate tirreth: wherefore good diet mut be ued, leat more matter be increaed, or naturall heate hindred.

In icke men (if they appeare in the crowne or circle) abundance of raw tough matter mixed with ventoitie and agitation thereof, which may ignifie colicke, head-ache, urfet. But if they appeare over the whole face of the urine, they ignifie weaknee of the head, flux of eed, weaknee of nature, through obtructions and raw humors. Alo if they appeare in the beginning of dieaes, an ill igne, becaue uch agitation, is of unnaturall heate, and accompanied with other ill ignes, as weaknes, old age, feeble, pule, winter, &c. mortall.

But appearing in the urine after the
beginning of dieaes with other good ignes, it is a good ignification of health, becaue uch agitation is of naturall heate now prevailing againt the dieae. But with other ill ignes, as ill colour and contents, &c. it giveth ill ignification that uch agitation is of unnaturall heate, and in weake perons, Death, but in trong perons, Long icknee, and great danger, Week.
Little. Little quantity of the pume, froth, bubbles.
Little or few, and dipered, two or three together ignifie lee head-ache and ventoity, &c. except the colour be yellow, for o choler increaeth the griefe.

div.head: Subtance of the pume, &c.
div.p: Thicke. Thicke, a better igne.
Thin. Thin, a wore igne epecially in agues ignifying great griefe, Bla. Holler. 162.

div.head: Time of appearance.
div.p: Time of appearance Not appearing at the firt, and afterwards appearing, ignifie concoction or declination of an ague. As in thicke urine. See there.
Differences of pume, froth and bubbles, be three.

1. Little bubbles (granula) like pinne-heads, Granula. or little droppes of quicke-ilver, decending downewards towards the wimme under the crowne into the body of the urine, ignifie griefes of the head, as rhewme, which ditilling downe into the inferiour parts of the body, as to the noe, maketh the poe, to the eyes, and caueth ophthalmie. To the eares, making a inging noye, and deafenee. To the pallat of the mouth, and maketh the uvula to fall downe. To the throat, and caueth hoarenee. To the mouth, and caueth exulcerations. To the jawes and mandible, tooth-ache. To the windepipe, the cough. To the lungs, hortnee of breath: to the guts, the colike, iliake, whereof ometime followeth a laske or flixe. To the tomacke, crudity. To the huckle-bone, ciatica. To the joynts in the hands, knees, and feet, the gout. To the reines, the nephreie. Alo the paages by which the rhewme ditilleth, are many, as the arteries, backbone, and veines: alo the meat-pipe, winde-pipe, and inewes. But the rhewme decending from the head by any of thee three lat, doth not necearily caue bubbles in the urine. We • .

2. Great bubbles (Ampullae) ignifie griefe in the reines (nephritis) for the reins being cold and farre ditant from the heart the fountaine of heate,Ampullae. and rhewmatike matter alo cold and heavy, and decending downeward, is alo drawne by the reines, and there for want of heate remaineth unconumed, and o breedeth griefe in the reines, in urine thin, and white bubbles. Alo according to Rhais fluxe of blood at the noe. If they be round, pluriie, Gout with rhewme and an ague.

Spume, foame. 3. Spume, froth, ignifie griefe in the middle members of the body, as heart liver, pleene, &c. riing of uch caues as the colours of the urine hew, Fern. 453. Windinee, collike. In yellow colour, the jaundice. In leadih oyly and palew, the phthiicke.

Note. ¶ But of fome, pume, aud bubbles, we can afely gather no generall precept, ave onely that they ignifie abundance of groe and raw humors, which being moved in the body, doe caue uch pume and bubbles, and o conequently length of the dieae in trong and luty perons, and death in weake and feeble,
epecially the pume and bubbles long continuing in great quantity, Salvian. 152.
Drops of oyle or fat. Spider-webs.Droppes of fat like pider-webbes, droppes of oyle wimming aloft, ignifie

1. Colliquation or conumption for the mot part mortall of the whole body, with an ague, and then this fat is pied lowly by little and little, at everall times, and in mal quantity, and well mixed or incorporated into the urine, but at the later end of the conumption when the patient is almot pent, this fat ceaeth to iue with the urine, being already diolved and voided, and the body decaying leane and dry, Salvian.

2. Colliquation of the reines and bladder onely without an ague, the fat being pied fat, uddenly, in good quantity, at once, and not o perfectly mixed with the urine, and with paine and heate about the reines. Yet Cardan aith, that hee himelfe oberved mall lender pider-webbes in his owne urine every day for 40. yeares together, and likewie in many other urines without any hurt at all, and therefore he thinketh that thee pider-webbes which ignifie colliquation
mut be greater, Salvian. 164.
3. Inflamation of the liver.
4. Criticall evacuation in concoction and declination of the dieae of ome humor offending, whereby ome fat member receiveth hurt, and o part of his fat is diolved, Salvian.
5. Oyle drunken, Fernel.

div.head: CHAP. IX.
Of the mell of Vrine.
div.p: No mell. SMell of urine is either none at all. 2. or weet. 3. or tinking.
No mell at all ignifieth extreame and mortall cold in harp dieaes, epecially if tinking urines were made before, and no eae of the patient ucceedeth, Salvian. 60. Vaae. 60. Argent. Montanus.
2. Sweet mell of the urine is either of caue externall, or internall.
Externall caue, as
Sweet mell. 1. Perfuming of the urine after it, is made with muske, junipet, ylphium, laerpitium, tyrax, roen of larch tree, or other perfume, Fernel. Bertin.

2. Eating of turpentine, &c. becaue it is not eaily changed in the body by reaon of his vicoity, nor draweth any tore of matter with it, Argent. 60. Salvian. 60. &c. Montanus thought, that by eating of weet melling things, the urine hould tincke, and contrariwie by eating of tinking things, the urine hould have a weet mell, whom Argenterin confuteth. For garlike tinketh, and being eaten, maketh the urine alo tinke, and contrary turpentine, hath of himelfe a good mell, which being taken into the body, giveth the ame mell to the urine.
Internall caue, as
Dominion of good blood not putrefied.
Ill or tinking mell. 3. Ill, or tinking mell, is likewie of caue externall, or internall.
Externall caue, as
1. Perfuming it with tinking perfumes, as aafetida, galbanum, agapenum, moke of burnt feathers, brimtone, &c.

2. Eating of Carduus benedictus (becaue it doth moove and tirre up the
humors, and converteth them to the paages of urine:) of rue, onyons, annie-eed, garlike, rotten cheee, talkes of perage, fenell, fengreeke, &c. Argent. Salvian. 98. Aegid. 11. Fernel. vide P. Apon. in problem. Arit. 2. 14.

div.head: Internall caue.
div.p:
Mens urines according to the divere contitutions of the bodies from whence they come, are in everall degrees of better or wore mell: for thoe who have abundance of pure blood and other humors according to their naturall dipoition, free from putrefaction, and expell their excrements both univerall and particular, in due time and quantity, and have a moderate ue of the ixe things not naturall, doe make urine (as all other excrements) lee tinking, yet omewhat ordinarily, becaue urine, as all other excrements, come of impure matter, and in mens bodies, which be moit, and ubject to putrefaction. Yet not in all bodies tinking ill, eeing it is concoct, Argent. And though it is too bae for the Phyitian, yea ometimes dangerous to put his noe to the urine, to dicerne the tinch thereof: yet the knowledge hereof hath good ue amongt other differences of urine,
yea, in demontrating putrefaction, ulcers, and impotumes in mans body, is to be preferred before all other, Argent. But to come to the matter againe. Stinking urines are evermore an argument of putrefaction, 1. either of the humours, 2. or olid and ubtantiall parts of mans body. Which you may ditinguih thus, for if the putrefaction be in the humors onely, the tinke began lately, and the urine is thicke or troubled, and chanceth by one of thee three waies: either for that the humors

Putrefaction of humors. 1. Breed crudity, through want of heat, as in thoe which are full of ill humors, as flegme and melancholy, becaue they make the urine thicker, and being cold, not provoking the veels to expulion, they tay longer in the body, and breed putrefaction.

2. Stay too long in the body, as in the trangury, dyury, tone, when the ediment is full of filth, and paine in piing, o in exulcerations or impotumes of the reines, or bladder and gonorrhoea, the urine white and thicke, and the ediment full of matter, Fernel. Salvian. 99. o in creticall evacuations of impotumes, and inflamations, with eae of the patient,
and ignes of concoction.
2. Are infected with the plague, in a confued and troubled, red urine, with little motes much dipered. With morbus gallicus, with andy and gravelly red contents.

Putrefaction of olid parts. But if the putrefaction be in the olid and ubtantiall parts of mans body, as the liver, pleene, veines, &c. it is with paine, and in urine rather thin then thicke; and the tinch of long continuance, for which caues there is great danger: for thin urine eldome tinketh, for want of putrefied humours and excrements. And tinch long continuing, heweth that the putrefaction is entred into the habit of the body, Cappivac. 112. Argenter.
¶Some ay that the urine tinketh in ome harp agues,Note. and dieaes, which Salvian denieth, ave only in the plague.

div.head: CHAP. X.
Of the manner of piing.
div.p: MAnner of piing, is either hard and uneaie: or ele involuntary.
Painefull piing. Painfull, hard, and uneaie piing is either becaue that the

1. Vrine is too harp (as in the trangury) by mixture of ome harp humours, as alt, flegme, choler, purulent matter: or by ill diet, or ome hot ditemperature in the veins, as in harp and continuall agues, or ome criticall evacuations. Or when the glandulous parts about the bladder are dried up by immoderate venery, dieae, or medicine, which hould mitigate the harpnee of the urine.

2. Veels of urine, reines, bladder, yard, either too weake, or troubled with exulcerations, by which urine paing caueth paine and marting. 2. Alo with impotumes, wellings, gatherings, in which the urine is firt white, then filthy, and latly rotten. 3. With inflammations, whereof followeth vomiting of choler, continuall ague, and paine in the reines,
Bertin. 4. With obtruction of the tone and gravell (as you may read, pag. 64.) Of tough and clammy humors, and ventoitie ditending the veels. 5. With ditemperature of heate and drinee. 6. With convulion of (phincter) the mucle hutting the necke of the bladder, or of the inewes adjoyning.
3. Blood, or the wombe is inflamed.
4. Guts, or the wombe ditended with tumors or ventoitie, as in the colicke, whereby the reins and emulgent veins are preed and traitned.
In voluntary piing, when one maketh urine unwittingly, or againt his wil, which happeneth either for that the

Involuntary piing. 1. Veels of urine, bladder, reines, &c. have their retentive faculty hurt, weakned, or decaied, as in the Apoplexy, falling icknee, pauley. Or when the mucle (phincter) hutting the necke of the bladder; Or inewes comming from the backe, erving thereto are hurt, by fall, beating, wound, &c. Or made feeble and weake by cold ditemperature, or by too much moiture in children, or drinee in old men, whereby the aforeaid mucle and inewes cannot detaine their urine, but many times they bepie their bed.
So in great and udden feare, when the blood, heate, and pirits, fly to the heart, and inward parts, whereby the outward parts, and thoe which be far ditant from the heart, are detitute of blood, heate, and pirits, o men uddenly terrified and atonied, not only void urine, but other excrements againt their will. Likewie in the piing ill, the urine white and much, and the patient thirty, and the body decaying. See before, cap. 5.

2. Principall Agent the braine not directing the animall faculty, nor communiting it the inewes and mucles of the veels of urine, whereupon they ceae from their function, and let the urine pae away by drops, as they receive it, as in mad men, raving, doting, in harp dieaes, but if there be other ignes of concoction, it ignifieth criticall fluxe of blood at the noe, becaue the matter being drawn up to the braine, and yet ignes of recovery, mut be voided at the noe, Salv. 113.

div.head: CHAP. XI.
Of uppreion of urine.
div.p: VRine is uppreed in whole men being occupied in ome importunate buines, as pleading at the barre, preaching, reading, &c. Alo leeping, whereby they cannot be at leiure, or ele forget, and o for a pace their urine is wholly uppreed, but in procee of time mut needs have iue, neither is it in mans free choyce alwaies to uppree his urine, though for a time he may. For it is not imply a voluntary action, as peaking and walking is, &c. but mixt partly voluntary, partly naturall, as cough, neeing, vomit, belching, ighing, repiration, &c. whereto we refer, evacuation by tool, and urine, &c. but eeing this uppreion of urine doth neither give ignification of icknee nor health, we leave further to peake of it.
Suppreion of urine in icke men. Suppreion of urine in icke men is either becaue the,
1. Veels of urine are weake and not able either to draw the matter of urine, or to expell it being made.

2. Watery humor the materiall caue
of urine is wanting, as in want of drinke or moit meats. 2. Or ele is converted another way, as in the dropie, Argenter. laskes, &c. But in thee caes the urine is rather little then none at all. See little quantity of urine before, cap. 6. 3. Or is obtructed and topped that it cannot haue iue either by ome tumor or inflamation accompanied with welling, paine, an ague, &c. or of chirrous welling without paine or ague: or impotume with paine or an ague, or latly, ome flehly ubtance, decending from ome ulcer, with ome blood and mall fragments of fleh voiding with the urine, and a yringe put up at the yard into the necke of the bladder, and removing the flehy fragments away, the urine preently iueth: or with the tone, and then gravell was voided before: or by clods of blood, remaining after ome iue of blood, or by ome purulent matter proceeding from an ulcer, or latly by ome thicke and groe humors, or filth and corruption decending from the veines, liver, or other uperiour members, which uppreion of urines in agues epecially continuall, ignifieth death more certainly, then any other igne in the
urine. In this cae Argenterius carcely ever knew any ecape death; unlee the fault be in the reines or bladder, Arg. 89. 4. Or when the bladder is o ditended, by too great quantity of urine too long kept, that it cannot unburden it elfe thereof, Wecker in Ichuria, and therefore it is convenient to pie, as often as need requireth, and not to keep it too long, for thereof arieth uppreion of urine (that we peake of) and omtime the tone, or difficulty in piing, and ometime the dropie; neither on the other ide do I commend their practie, who like dogs are till piing, for beides many other inconveniences, they bring their veels of urine to uch an ill cutome, that in old age (when the retentive faculty through want of heate decaying) they can carcely hold their urine, but it will iue from them againt their will. But I wih all men to void their excrements both by toole (for being too long kept in the body, they annoy the head by their tinking fume acending, breed ventoities, wringing in the guts, cholike, &c.) and by urine, that they may follow their ordinary coure of life, for therefore nature hath appointed mucles to the neck of the bladder, and eat, that men may
at their pleaure detaine their excrements for ome pace. Placotomus de tuenda valitudine.

2. Sometime the greater guts are o obtructed through tough and vicous flegme, that the meat and drink concocted in the tomacke, cannot come to the liver to receive further concoction and eparation of urine, Holl. lib. 1. cap. 47. de morbis internis.
4. Sometime the backebone is bruied, broken, or hath ome dilocation in the joynts: that thereby the veels of urine cannot performe their duty, Wecker.

div.head: CHAP. XII.
Of what parts of the body urine giveth ignification.
div.p: VRine giveth ignification of dieaes of uch parts of the body,

1. Whence it receiveth matter wherof it is made colour, ubtance, contents, darknee, perpecuity, mell, as the tomacke, guts, mearaicall veines, and
all other parts of the body, for the materiall caue of urine is drinke, or other liquor, which in the tomacke is accurately mixed and incorporated together with the meat, and made one ubtance and white juice called of the phyitians Chylas, which decending into the winding capacity of the guts is eparated partly into excrement, and partly nourihment. For the purer part thereof is ucked of the mearaicall veines, and conveyed thence to vena porta, and at length to the liver, where being converted into blood, and the excrementitions parts thereof, equetred and ent to their proper receptacles, as choler to the gall, melancholy to the pleene, and the watry thin part to the reines, but not all, for ome part thereof together with the blood (which it maketh thinner for more eaie conveyance) is ditributed into every member of the body. From whence o much as is not pent in the body, or evaporated out by weat, or inenible perpiration, returneth backe againe the ame way to the liver, whence it is drawn of the emulgent veines, and decendeth to the reines and bladder. Therefore urine is not onely made of that watery
ubtance which is drawne from the liver, but alo from the greater and lee veines, and from the whole body. As hee may eaily and plainly perceive by experience, who will for three or foure dayes together, either receive no drinke at all, or but little. The urine therefore, that is neither too thin by much quaffing, nor otherwie polluted by mixture of other impurities, doth manifetly hew the tate and contitution of the humors which are in the liver and greater veines. And alo, though not o manifetly, in the maller veines and all other parts of the body, Fernel.
2. Where it is made, as the liver, and the hollow veine.
3. By which it paeth, as the emulgent veines, reines, and water conduits.
4. Wherein it tayeth, as the bladder with his mucles and inewes.
5. By which it is expelled, as the yard.

6. Which doe deprive it of any colour, ubtance, perpecuity, darkenee, quantity, contents or mell, as when it is not made, or being made is not attracted, or not expelled, or obtructed and topped in the veels that it cannot have paage to be voided, as
by rumors, groe humors, tone, gravell, inflammations, ulcers, impotumes, fleh growing, winde, or through weaknee, ditemperature, fractures, ruptures, dilocations, wounds of the veels of urine, either primary in themelves, or by conent of others, &c. Or being made, is converted another way, as to the head in phrenies, to the tomacke in vomitings, to the belly in dropies, to the guts in lasks, to the mother in fluxe of tearmes, to the cods in ruptures, to the joynts in ciatica, gout, to the parts weak, grieved, inflamed, apotomated, &c.

7. Which doe exonerate themelves by urine, as the head in rhewmes, phrenies, &c. The throat in the quinie, the lungs in inflammations, the olid parts in a conumption, the pleene in melancholike dieaes, the veines or arteries broken, in piing of blood, the permatike veels, in fluxe of eed, the mother in tearmes uppreed and voided by urine the hemorrhoidall veins in the emeraudes, the joynts in the ciatica, or gout, and divere other parts of the body in evacuation, criticall, ymptomaticall, or artificiall.

Of all thee you may finde everall
examples in this treatie precedent.

div.head: CHAP. XIII.
Of crude, concoct, and dangerous urines.
div.p: BEcaue mention is often made heretofore, of crude, concoct, and dangerous urines, as alo that they be very needfull to be known perfectly, & alwayes had in memory; eeing they comprehend in few words, the um of all that hath heretofore bin poken. I thought good in the end to adde the decription thereof.

Concoct urine.Concoct urine, uch as men onely make who are in ome latitude of health, is in
colour
palew,
light affron.
ubtance, meane.
contents
equall,
white,
light.
mell, not tinking.
piing in due time without
paine,
heate,
cold.

Crude urine. Crude urines onely. Such as men make inclining to icknes, or recovering after icknee, is in
colour
white,
pale,
affron,
claret,
ubtance
thicker,
thinner.
contents
whitih,
pale,
omewhat unequall.
mell, not much tinking.
piing not in due time.
Vrines meane betwixt crude and concoct, are of two orts. 1. For either they encline more to concoct. Such as have a good colour, but thin ubtance. Alo a white and light ediment, but not equall.
2. Or ele they encline more to crude. Such as have reddih colour, like to water wherein raw fleh hath been wahed, which are made of blood not perfectly concoct.

Vrin crude and dangerous.Vrine, Crude and dangerous, uch as men make who are grievouly icke and in danger not to recover, is in
colour
greene,
ah colour,
blacke.
ubtance
very thin,
very thicke,
oyly.
contents
greene,
ah colour,
oyly,
blacke,
very unequall,
deformed.
mell very tinging.
piing altogether out of due time. Or not at all, B. Holler. 270. Cappiva • . 195.

div.head: CHAP. XIV.
Of methodicall practie in iudgement of Vrines.
div.p: Coniderations fit for practie. BEfore you give judgement of the urine; it is needfull that you meditate with your elfe on thee precepts following in order.

1. Remember the generall coniderations in the firt chapter,
both concerning the urinall and the urine. As alo which be the bet urines imply, and in repect of age, exe, complexion, time of the yeare, kinde of life, &c. which you may have o perfectly in memory, that you can preently tell how farre that urine which is brought unto you, differeth from a good urine, in colour, ubtance, contents, &c.

2. Whether the urine be altered by ome externall caue mentioned in the firt chapter and throughout the booke; or ele through default of the reines and bladder by which the urine paeth. For thee two impediments either everall or concurring, hinder the judgement of the inner parts, Fernel. 443.

3. Conider what dieaes are incident to the countrey where the patient dwelleth, or what common dieae is their tirrings: as for example, if the patient be an old man, and in winter, rainy weather, and in a moit and fennih countrey, it can hardly be otherwie, but that he is troubled with a cough, rhewme, poe, and lacke of digetion, and the rather if he be given to urfetting, much drinking, and bee of a flegmatike complexion, and heretofore troubled with rhewmatike dieaes. But
contrariwie, if hee be a young man, and cholerike, in the middle of ummer, hote weather, hote climate, after hote diet and immoderate exercie, it is very likely, that he is troubled with a burning ague, tertian, flixe, or plureie, to which of thee he is mot ubject, or which at that time is mot tirring in that countrey. After this ort you may judge of other dieaes without helpe of the urine.

Three caues of internall dieaes. 4. If the urine be faulty, and yet neither through externall caue, nor of the reines, then it mut needs hew ome ditemperature of the inward parts, heart, liver, pleene, lungs, veines, or other part of the body. Which ditemperature is either imple, without mixture of humors, which colour of the urine in thin ubtance will hew, or with mixture of humors in a thicke and troubled ubtance, or ele putrefaction, in a confued urine. Which three be the internall caues almot of all dieaes, whereby you have already attained no mall knowledge, what to doe, or what evacuation is convenient for the cure of the dieae, although you cannot as yet, particularly undertand the ame. Fernel.

5. Of all differences of urines colour
is mot mutable and uncertaine of ignification, Which difference of urine is to bee preferred in certainty of ignification, and wherein. as being ubject to many alterations of light caue. As by much drinking, thin drinke, as water, white wine, or by eating of hote pices, ena, caia, &c. yea in one day every urine that a man maketh is unlike an other in colour, o that here epecially the infamy that urine is a lying trumpet, hath ome appearance of truth. Contrariwie the contents of urine are of mot certaine and true ignification of all other, and leat ubject to alteration, for that they are either fragments of the parts of the body, or contained in the parts. Of thee Hippocrates and Galen epecially make mention, not greatly regarding the ret. The other differences of urine, ubtance, perpecuity, darknee, quantity, mell, &c. are of meane ignification betwixt colour and contents. And yet every difference hath peciall ignification above the ret in ome dieaes:Smell. for tinking mell of urines giveth more perfit ignification of putrefaction, ulcers, or impotumes, then either colour, ubtance, or contents. Suppreion of urine, in agues epecially continuall,Suppreion. giveth more certaine ignification of death, then thin
ubtance, ill colour, or want of contents: for thee hew one crudity, which in time is curable: but the other happeneth through great obtructions of the reines, liver, or other uperiour member, which at that time are incurable.Colours. Colours of urine collected in due time, from an orderly patient, giveth better ignification of the humor loffending in the body, then any other. Lat
• y, Contents. contents iuing with the urine, doe epecially ignifie trength of nature, which in time will prevaile againt the dieae. For when the digetive faculty is weake, the matter whereof contents arie, cannot be overcome and prepared to be voided. So that every difference of urine hath ome peciall ignification above the ret, Arg. 89.

6. Alo you mut often ee the patients urine on divers daies and divers times of his icknes, and diligently marke the pereverance or alteration of the urine from time to time, and whether it change from wore to better or otherwie.How the urine altereth in dieaes. For as the patient recovereth, nature proceedeth orderly and by degrees from unperfect to perfect, from icknee to health, and o by little and little changeth the urine: firt, the colour, which is eaiet: econdly,
it waxeth cleerer; thirdly, the ubtance waxeth meane betwixt thin and thicke; fourthly, when concoction is tronger, contents appeare. And therefore if contents appeare firt before colour, cleernee or ubtance, there is the lee ecurity of health: becaue this is not the orderly coure of nature, but ome ymptomaticall fit of the dieae, which will oone vanih away and decay. And therefore to good purpoe mut you alwaies remember this theorem commonly received of the Phyitians, that nature ordinarily firt conformeth the colour, then the ubtance, and latly the contents, Mont. 52.

How the colour altereth. This is the orderly coure and proceeding of nature in repect of the colour. In the beginning of dieaes, when all the humors are raw, the urine is white. In the increae and tate of the dieae, higher and deeper colours. In the declining, more remie againe, untill at length it returneth to his meane colour againe.

How the ubtance altereth. In repect of the ubtance, in the beginning it is thin, for nature hath yet made no eparation. In the increae and tate it waxeth more thicke and troubled, through naturall heate now beginning to worke ome eparation and expulion of the humor,
in declining it waxeth cleerer and thinner againe, when naturall heate doth attenuate, rareie; and deipate the flatuous and groe humors, and o the urine waxeth lee troubled. To conclude, for ubtance of urine marke thee foure differences.
1. Firt thin, and o continuing, is wort of all, ignifying extreame crudity.
2. Firt thin, and afterwards waxeth thicker, and more troubled, better then the former both for heate and trength of nature.
3. Firt troubled and thicke, and o continuing, better then the two former, for better heate, and more lively trength of nature.

4. Firt thicke and troubled, and afterwards clearing and waxing thinner, the thicker part etling downe to the ediment, bet of all in dieaes, as now almot returning to a meane ubtance, uch as is in whole mens urines.

How the contents alter. In repect of contents not altogether unnaturall. In beginning of humorall dieaes through crudity there appeare no contents at all in increae and tate, the dieae continuing trong, and naturall
heate weake, ome though few in declination, when nature waxeth tronger prevailing againt the dieae, moe contents appeare, and firt in the cloud or uppermot region, then in the middle region or wimme, and latly in the ediment.

¶ And this is the ordinary alteration of urine in all humorall dieaes wherein is good hope of recovery (except it be accidentally hindred by obtruction or converion another way, and which have ditinction of time of beginning, increae, tate and declination. For harp dieaes through their vehement and furious aaults, do not admit uch peciall ditinction.

8. Latly, it is good for him that now beginneth to practie, and hath not as yet attained to ome good meaure of skill, to exercie himelfe in thee three, as principall guides of all his judgements, &c. The bet urine, pag. 6. Crude, concoct, and dangerous urines, pag. 105. and epecially mortall urins which have ignification of death, wherein the credit of the Phyitian chiefly coniteth. For which purpoe in the alphabeticall index under death I have collected all mortall dieaes, whereof urine giveth ignification in this treatie. But yet it is not the afet way reolutely to prognoticate
death by them, epecially in a young and luty man, except other ill ignes concurre, as want of trength, pule, feeble, and inordinate ra • ing breathing with difficulty, lacke of ret, hollow eyes, harp noe, in voluntary weeping, gathering of traws and flocks, want of leep and appetite, cold weat, trembling of the nether lip, excrement by toole, blacke, greene, or tinking, &c. But contrariwie if the patient draw his breath with eae, have a good pule, be trong, lye in bed decently, have a cheerefull countenance, his leep and appetite not much decayed, and his excrements not altogether unnaturall, doe confirme good hope of recovery. And in like ort in all ignifications of urine be not too confident, but adde other pathog •• monicall igns for better confirmation and more certaine ignification of the kinde, nature, and quality of the dieae. Et qu • non prount ingula, multa i • va • t.

div.head: CHAP. XV.
Of the qualities, commodities, and medicines of urine: and of dieaes touching urine, and the remedies thereof.
div.p: HItherto we have compendiouly handled the differences, caues, and judgements of urine. But that the treatie may be more abolute, we will adde omething more of the qualities, and benefit of urine which it hath either inwardly received, or outwardly applied to mans body.

div.head: The quality of Vrine.
div.p:
All urine (as Galen aith, lib. 10. de impl. medie. facult. de urina) is hot and harp (as Aegineta thinketh) but yet differing in degree according to them that make it. For the hotter they are that make it, in complexion, age, time of the yere, and diet, the hotter it is alo; yet mans urine (wherof we peake) is the weaket of all other, except tame barrow-hogs, which in many points agree with man, yet it is alo of a trong clening or abterive vertue, as any thing ele, which Galen proveth by the
example of fullers, who ue it to skoure and clene their cloath.
The commodity and medicines of urine being taken inwardly.
A mans owne urine drunken is good againt the biting of vipers, and poyon, and againt the dropie lately begun. Dioc. lib. 2. cap. 27.

A childes urine under the age of 14 yeares being drunken, helpeth thoe that are troubled with traitnee of breath (orthoponea) which though Galen reporting derideth as inufficient and loathome, yet Avicen. lib. 2. can. cap. proprio. doth greatly commend, for that by experience in many dieaed perons he found it true.

A mans urine is good for divere dieaes of the wombe and bowels, epecially for the collicke: becaue that partly with provoking of vomit, and partly by occaion of ieges, it expelleth trongly all noyome humors, and for the ame caue doe common practitioners keep it till in daily ue. Recordè Marcello.

Vldericke Hutten alo witneeth, that he did drive away the ague above eight times with the only drinking of his owne urine, at the beginning of his icknee,
which practie many till doe ue, and it proveth well.
Likewie Galen, Paul Aegin • ta and Marilius Ficinus write that divere drinking urine did think themelves preerved and cured from the petilence.

Vrine as Cardan aith, through his heate is of a thin and piercing ubtance, o that it is lighter then ome water, notwithtanding his altnee, for which caue it is good againt the colicke and ventoitie in the guts farre above alt water, for through his ubtle and piercing ubtance it findeth paage to the inward parts, and through his altnes it cattereth, breaketh, and dipereth the ventoitie, and trengtheneth the inward parts. But to this purpoe a childes urine under fourteen yeares old, and lately made is bet, for that is mot piercing and hot. Cardan de ubtilitate, lib. 17.
Medicines of urine outwardly applyed.

Vrine is good againt the itch, and cleneth the leproie, mixt with alt-peter: tale pie cleneth running ulcers of the head, curfe, manginee, and hot breakings out, it tayeth eating ulcers epecially in the privy members, and being put into
the eares, it cleneth the rotten and purulent matter, and being odden in the rinde of a Pomegrante killeth the wormes thereof, odden in a braen veell with honey, doth clene the carres of the eyes, and cleereth the dimnee thereof, the dregs of urine is good for Saint Anthonies evill, if it be anointed thereon, o that (as as Galen doth wiely adde) the ore being cooled firt with ome other thing, and be not burning. If it bee heated with oyle of privet, and layd to the wombe of a woman, it will awage the griefe of the mother, and cureth the riing of the ame, it cleneth the eye-lids, and carres of the ame, Diocor. lib. 2. cap. 17.

Galen almot to the ame purpoe aith thus of urine: mens urine is of a trong clening vertue as any thing els, and therewith doe fullers ue to coure and clene their cloath, which abterive faculty Phyitians perceiving, did ue it to oke, and wah manginee and cabbednee, and running ores that are full of corruption, and filth, and epecially if they have in them putrefied matter, & for uch ores on the privy members it is good, and for mattering eares, and for cales and
curfe, if the head be wahed therewith. I have healed with it many times ores on the tooes, namely which came of bruies, and were without inflammation, and that in ervants and husbandmen, which had a journey to goe, and no Phyitian with them, bidding them to wet a mall clout with it, and put it into the ores, and then to binde a cloth about it: and as often as they lited to make water, to let it fall on their ore toes, and not to take the cloath away till it were quite whole. That medicine which is made of childes urine, called chryocolla, or gold ouder, which Galen there teacheth to make, is exceeding good for ores that are hard to heale: for this medicine doe I ue for the chiefet, mixing therewith uch other things, as are good for uch like ores. Galen, lib. 10. de implie. med. facult. cap. de urina.
Childes urine will heale the ting of a Bee, Wape, and Hornet, if the place be wahed therewith.

It is good for travellers when they goe to bed to wah their thighes therewith, that they may be able to continue their journey the next day, and the rather, if afterwards they anoint them
with oyle and juice of rue.

Mans urine is alo good againt the gout, which may appeare for that fullers are never troubled with the gout, by reaon that their feet are o often wahed with it, and ome who have had good experience thereof with great uccee, doe highly commend it for this purpoe.

Seeing then urine hath o many commodities, and was in antient time in o great ue (as Diocorides, Galen, Pliny, Columella, and all thoe that have written of cure of hores, doe ufficiently tetifie) it came to pae, that the Emperours of Rome got yearely revenues by urines, as Suetonius reporteth of Vepaian, who anwered Titus reprehending him for eeking after gaines by uch tinking wares, in this proverbiall entence, Bonus et odor lucri ex requalibet.

div.head: Of dieaes touching Vrine, and the remedies thereof.
div.p:
REcord in the latter end of his judiciall of urines, etteth downe certain imple medicines for ome dieaes which hinder urine, by whoe example not altogether
impertinent to this treatie: I have likewie collected a briefe hitory of the aid dieaes with ome medicines thereof. And firt of the tone.

The tone is engendred in mans body, as a bricke which is firt made of tough clay, and put into an hot furnace where it waxeth hard; o a tone is made of tough, vicous, and limy flegme in the reines or bladder, where through heate thereof it is parched and baked together into the hardnee of a tone. But that I may peake omewhat fullier thereof, and yet briefly, the materiall caue of the tone is, as I aid, a tough limy flegme, and all caues which increae the ame, as all crudities and urfeits, all meats groe, limy, and hard of digetion, as milke, new cheee, all white meats made of milke, all cruts of flower wherein meat is baked, bread not well baked, unleavened. All fleh of great beats, epecially old, as beefe, venion: and all water-foule. Great fihes, epecially thoe who abound in limy moiture, as eeles, all hell-fih, oyters, cockles, lopters, crevies. All fruits which engender groe humors, peares, apples
gourds. Roots which breed winde, as parneps, turneps. Alo all new and thicke wine and drinke. Likewie becaue heate of the reines doth bake and harden the aid flegme, and all caues which increae heate in the reines, as too warme apparell whereby the backe and reines are kept too hot, running, leaping, violent exercie: alo riding epecially with his backe towards the Sunne, tanding againt the fire with his backe, and meats, drinks, and pices which increae heate. Alo when the veels of urine, the reines, &c. have too trait paages, whereby that limy flegme cannot have iue to be expelled, but taieth within, and thorough heate waxeth hard, whereupon fat men through moitnee, and old men through drinee, having traight paages in the reines, are more ubject to the tone in the reines, and lee in the bladder: contrariwie, children though they are hot and abound with flegme thorough ill diet, yet becaue their reines are wider and expulive faculty trong, whereby that flegmy matter is voyded, are lee troubled with the tone of the reines, neither leane men for the elfeame caue, but both of them are rather
troubled with tone of the bladder, Hippor. 3. Aphori. 26. Latly, an epeciall caue of the tone are the parents, from whom this grievous hereditary dieae doth decend upon the childe: and this of all other is hardet to be cuerd. Now with like brevity to come to the cure, eeing there be foure caues which help to breed the tone, tough and limy flegme, heate to parch and drie it, traitnee of the paage, and weaknee of the expulive faculty. So many things as take away any of thee, helpe for the cure thereof, as firt a good diet, brothes wherein borage, fenell, parley, endive, or uccory is odden, bread well baked and leavened, hennes, capons, partridge, mutton. Of fih, oles, plaice, trouts, almons. Of herbs, borage, endive, uccorie, perage, beetes. And to come to the cure. A vomit at the beginning and divere times, is of epeciall ue to draw the flegmy matter away from the reines and bladder: then a uppoitary, to draw ome uperfluous excrements downewards, and a clyter is to be preferred before a purgation becaue it draweth the excrements downewards from the reines, whereas a purgation taken by the
mouth doth alwaies draw ome impurity downewards to the reines, but yet the cliter may not be too great in quantity, let it fill the guts, and ditend the reines, and o increae the paine, and top the paage. After that, if the body be full of blood, open the veine under the anckle and not in the arme (as ome would) for all parts of the body grieved above the liver, would be eaed by opening a veine in the arme, but under the liver, by opening the veine under the anckle or under the knee. Galen Comment. lib. 9. Hippoc. de morbis vulneribus. Galen de vena ectione, and then if the body abound with other humors a purgation is convenient, but not trong at the firt, let it tirre the humors too much out of eaon before the paages be open. After this eeke to open the paages of urine about the reines partly with clyter, partly outwardly by ome fomentation, lineaments, ineions, but yet too much ue of thee doth effoeminate the reines, and make them more ubject to the humors decending. Then at length you may miniter medicines which provoke urine, breake and expell the tone. Of which medicines there is great diverity. For ome help to
mitigate the heate of the reins, awage the inflammation, and hinder the gravell to grow together into a tone, and uch be cooling, enifiers of roughnee, but not atringent, as the foure lee cold eeds.

2. Some provoke urine either for that they augment it by attenuating the blood, and eparating it from the wheyih ubtance, and carrying it to the reins, & thee are hot and dry towards the third degree.

3. Or ome provoke urine, becaue they miniter much watery and wheyih moiture to the body, which the reins drawing to them, doe alo draw ome humors out of the veines, as white wine, plantaine, and melons eed.

4. Or ome againe provoke urine, not by augmenting the quantity, but by clening, skouring the reines, and diolving and expelling gravell now beginning to grow together. As turpentine, root of retharrow, betony, fenell eed and root, perage, juice of limmons, root of orrell, maiden haire, ceterac.
5. Some againe provoke urine by both thee qualities, in minitring much wheyih matter, & alo by clening the paages.

6. Some provoke urine by their roughnee, clening the reines, and robbing or
fretting on the tone or gravell, as glae burned and beaten into pouder, eggehels, gromill, the tone it elf which came from a man beaten into pouder.
7 Latly, ome provoke urine by an hidden and ecret property, as lapis Iudaicus, caia, rheubarbe.

Thoe medicines which provoke urine in the econd ignification by augmenting the quantity, are never to be ued in any dieae of the veels of urine as emulgent veines, reines, water-conduits, bladder or yard, for thereby they are more hurt and obtructed by much quantity of urine paing that way. But uch medicines which doe coole the heate of the reins, or which do clene and mundefie them from impurity, already gathered, and neither exceed in heat or drinee, but in ubtle and piercing quality. Or which by propriety of their ubtance help that way, as thoe in the fourth and eventh ignification, and yet thee are not at all, or eldome to be ued, when the body is leane or in a conumption, or full of blood and ill humors, neither when the veels of urine are exulcerated or obtructed, or the paages trait, or when the wombe or privy members have any welling or ulcer; or when
the urine is uppreed, the bladder being full, or iueth with mart burning. For in all thee the medicines bring more impurity to the places grieved, and o increae the dieae, neither are they to be ued in wellings or breakings out of the skin, let they draw the griefe to the inward parts.

div.head: Of the trangury.
div.p:
The trangury is caued either for that the urine is too harp, which doth provoke the expulive faculty to expell it, before any quantity be gathered together. Or for that the retentive faculty to the bladder is weakened through ome ditemperature, epecially of cold. Or ele through ome ulcer or inflammation of the bladder, to which the urine comming doth extimulate the expulive faculty. Or latly, when the wombe or bowels being inflamed, or wollen, do trouble or ditend the bladder, as in women great with childe, who oftentimes pie little and often. Now as the caue of the griefe is divere, o the medicines is likewie divere for harpnes of the urine, whether it come of hot and alt meats, too much heating the liver and reines, or of medicines which burne the blood, or of exercie which likewie heate
the reines and bladder, or latly, that the moiture in the glandulous parts is dried up by too much ue of venery, leanenee or drinee of the body, mut bee cured with contrary diet, and medicine which moiten, take away the harpnee and coole the blood as new laid egges, chickens, veale, meats made of wheat and barley meale, alo lettuce, purlane, endive, orrell, prunes, cherries, weet apples, cucumbers, melons, but mixe not here with too much alt, vineger, or other hot pices, and if the body abound with harp humors a gentle purgation is good of caia, manna, whey, dieebaten, alo decoctions of lettuce, violets, orrell, purlane, adding thereto ome licorize or prunes, the flowers or leaves of malowes, the root of holihoke. And if the paine be raging, it is good to make an injection by a yringe, of the white of an egge, with roe water or womans milke, or the juice of purlane, or plantaine, &c. But if the glandulous moiture be too much dried up, you mut ue uch meats and medicines inwardly and outwardly as doe moiten the parts, as oyle of violets, almonds, hennes greae, new butter alo to make plaiters to be applied to the places about the privy members
or injections, to be quirted up into the yard or cliters to the ame purpoe.

div.head: Of the piing evill.
div.p:
The piing evill is called, when the patient pieth as fat as he drinketh, and in like quantity. Or when he pieth againt his will, and it chanceth either through default of the bladder or reines. As when the retentive faculty of the bladder is decaied through ditemperature of cold and moitnee: for too much cold doth extinguih the naturall heate of it, which is of a cold and inewie ubtance, and without blood, and too much moitnee doth looen the mall trings, erving to the retentive faculty, or when the expulive faculty is hurt through quantity or quality of the urine. Or latly, when the mucle (phincter erving for voluntary motion, is decaied or weakened either through cold or moitnee, looening, or obtructing or benumming the mucle, as in the paulie, or is rent or wounded that it cannot doe his duty, as ome time happeneth to thoe, who are cut for the tone in the bladder, where either the unskilfull Surgeon doth make too great inciion, or the tone too big doth rent the mucle in comming out. Whereupon though
the wound groweth whole againe, yet the weaknee of the mucle remaineth: this griefe is almot familiar to children who bepie their beds in leep through weaknee and looenee. Or this griefe happeneth through default of the reines being too hot, and o draw the urine too fat from the liver and veines, and the retentive faculty weak cannot hold the urine, but endeth it as fat to the bladder.

Now for the cure (but I can ay nothing of the cure of the mucle of the bladder, for that being cut or wounded, &c. incurable.) Firt the humor offending mut be removed, and then the ditemperature corrected, the humor offending if it be heate, mut be removed by opening the liver veine in the right arme, or by a gentle purgation of manna caia, tamarindes, irupe of roes olutine, diaebeten, and diaprunon, but all without cammony and rather often to be ued, then much at once, that thereby nature by little and little may be framed to void thoe humors by toole which decend to the reines, alo a vomite tronger for to draw the humors from the reines, and a weat is not inconvenient to draw them to the skin, and latly to correct the ditemperature,
and trengthen the parts, ue ome of thee cooling medicines, as lettuce, endive, uckory, forrell, alo decoctions and irups of the ame, and beides of purlane, roes, violets, and cooling meats and drinks. For trong wines, and which have power to provoke urine are not good. Alo a ceare-cloth applyed to the backe, loynes and veines to coole them, ceratum refrigerans, unguentum roaceum & antalinam meue. But if the caue came of cold, a vomit and weat is likewie good, alo clyters, wherein oyle of cammomill, dill and bitter almonds mut be ued. And now and then it is good to ue pils of aloes and rheubarbe. The diet mut be of hote things, and wherein ome hot pices are put. Latly, ue of cupping glaes without inciion, friction of the outward parts, and moderate exercie is convenient, both becaue they heate the body, as alo draw the humor away from the inward parts. And thus much briefly of thee dieaes, not intending fully to handle the ame.
